bysharon otterman , ernesto londoñoandnicholas bogel-burroughs for the fourth time in six month , the republican-led house committee on education and the workforce is summoning school leader to washington to be questioned about accusation of antisemitism at their institution . this time , on thursday , the committee ’ s focus will be on how three diverse university reacted when pro-palestinian encampment sprung up on their lawn a part of an international wave of student activism against the war in gaza . two of the school whose leader will testify — northwestern and rutgers — made deal with protester to end their encampment peacefully . the third , the university of california , los angeles , called in the police to dismantle it encampment , but only after a violent attack by counterprotesters the night before caused the situation toveer out of control . representative virginia foxx , the chairwoman of the committee , ha blasted rutgers and northwestern for negotiating with the demonstrator , whose view she ha described a antisemitic and supportive of terrorism . but she ha also derided u.c.l.a . ’ s chancellor for calling the police too late , saying he allowed his campus to become a “ severe and pervasive hostile environment for jewish student . ” “ the committee ha a clear message for mealy-mouthed , spineless college leader : congress will not tolerate your dereliction of your duty to your jewish student , ” m . foxx said in amay 16 statementannouncing the hearing . “ no stone must go unturned while building are being defaced , campus green are being captured or graduation are being ruined . ” the three college leader do not dispute that jewish student have faced antisemitism , both on and off their campus . but all have largely defended their response , saying that they have taken step to stop it . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience place around 11 a.m . saturday , when force located the four hostage in two separate building where they were being held by hamas militant . he said the israeli force came under fire but managed to medical condition and were transferred to a hospital in israel for further examination , the israeli authority said in a statement . the fate of the hostage ha been a source of intense political Body Text: advertisement supported by the republican-written bill , which the white house strongly opposes , stand little chance of becoming law after lawmaker failed to reach a bipartisan deal on penalizing measure . byrobert jimison reporting from the capitol the house voted mostly along party line on tuesday to impose sweeping sanction on official at the international criminal court in a rebuke of effort by the court ’ s top prosecutor tocharge top israeli leaderswith war crime in connection with the offensive against hamas . the bill would compel president biden to restrict entry into the united state , revoke visa and impose financial restriction on anyone at the court involved in trying to investigate , arrest , detain or prosecute “ protected person , ” or ally of the united state . it would also target anyone who provides “ financial , material or technological support ” to those effort . mr . biden ’ s adviser said he wa “ strongly opposed ” to the measure because it would impose sanction on such a broad swath of official , including court staff member and any witness involved in a potential case . but it reflected broad bipartisan anger in washington after the court ’ s top prosecutor announced late last month that he wouldseek charge against both israeli and hamas leader . the g.o.p . - written bill passed by a vote of 247 to 155 , with two republican voting present and 42 democrat crossing party line in support . representative chip roy , republican of texas and the author of the bill , said it wa a necessary step to stop the international court from acting beyond it jurisdiction and to address fear that action taken against israeli official could be a prelude to action against american official . “ what happens here is going to be coming at u and our country , ” mr . roy said on tuesday . “ that ’ s why it ’ s important to speak with one voice , with authority , with force . ” we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in reader mode please exit andlog intoyour time account , orsubscribefor all of the time . thank you for your patience while we verify access . already a subscriber ? log in . want all of the time ? subscribe . advertisement

Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement the vote wa aimed at keeping the divisive issue in the hand of legislator instead of judge , who have repeatedly determined that an exemption should not stand . byephrat livni israel ’ s parliament on tuesday voted to revive a bill that would enable ultra-orthodox men to be drafted into the military , a divisive issue that ha become especially contentious since the war in gaza began last october . the vote , which passed 63-57 , wa a procedural step aimed at keeping the hot-button issue in the hand of legislator instead of judge , who have repeatedly determined thatthe exemption , dating to the founding of israel , should not stand . many secular israeli have long lamented the draft exemption for the most religious member of society . the issue ha taken new prominence since the hamas-led attack in israel on oct . 7 set off a war that ha prompted repeated call-ups of reserve soldier . the bill , which revives a proposal made in 2022 , would limit the exemption for young ultra-orthodox men enrolled in religious study , establish recruitment quota for them and provide alternative service option , among other change . some critic contend , however , that the proposal would not significantly increase military service among the ultra-orthodox , known in hebrew a haredi . the bill wa advanced in may by prime minister benjamin netanyahu , in an apparent effort to deter israel ’ s supreme court from taking the lead on the matter.the justice are currently considering whether the government must immediately begin drafting the ultra-orthodox , following the expiration of a law last year that wa temporarily extended and ha expired again . the vote on tuesday wa widely seen a intended to send a signal to the court that the knesset wa addressing the issue . the court ordered the government to address it long ago , but year of legislative effort have failed to produce meaningful change . we are having trouble retrieving Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement u.s . air force cargo plane dropped 36,800 ready-to-eat meal , in a joint operation with the jordanian air force , but a pentagon spokesman said were no plan to prevent a greater humanitarian disaster in the palestinian territory . u.s . air force cargo plane dropped 36,800 ready-to-eat meal , in a joint operation with the jordanian air force , “ to provide essential relief to civilian affected by the ongoing conflict , ” u.s . central command said in a statement on tuesday . it said that army troop trained in aerial delivery were part of the airdrop , and that it wa planning more such mission . however , the pentagon said on tuesday that the united state did not intend to send it troop into gaza to strengthen the aid distribution process . “ at this time there are no plan to put u.s . force on the ground in gaza , ” maj . gen . patrick ryder , a pentagon spokesman , said at a news conference . some aid expert and humanitarian group have criticized the american airdrop a insufficient and largely symbolic , given the scale of the hunger problem facing gaza after five month of war . cargo plane can only move a fraction of the food a convoy of truck can deliver , expert say , and a better solution would be for the united state to persuade israel to open more border crossing and speed up inspection . the operation on tuesday followed a first round of airdrop on saturday , two day aftermore than 100 palestinian were killedas israeli force opened fire around a convoy of aid truck in northern gaza . doctor at gaza hospital said most of the casualty were from gunfire . the israeli military said most of the victim were trampled a they tried to seize the cargo , although israeli official acknowledged that troop had fired on some people who they said had threatened them . after the convoy killing , president biden said the united state would find new way to get aid to palestinian in desperate need because of israel ’ s five-month military campaign to destroy hamas . only atrickle of aidhas been reaching northern gaza via land , but aid group have criticized airdrop asineffective . the amount of aid delivered by a french plane in anairdroplast week wa much less than a single truckload . although mr . biden ha implored israel , which ha largely sealed it border with gaza , to clear the way for more aid delivery , the demand for food , water and medicine there remains huge . those condition have put mr . biden under political pressure to do more to help the palestinian , even a the united state supply israel with military hardware . despite his frustration with israel ’ s political leadership , mr . biden ha not threatened to put limit on american military aid to the country . helene cooperis a pentagon correspondent . she wa previously an editor , diplomatic correspondent and white house correspondent.more about helene cooper advertisement

matter protest . last fall , police official and m . james reached the agreement in federal court , intended to strike a new equilibrium between the department ’ s need to preserve public safety and the right of protester . the city , along with two major police union , agreed to develop policy and training that would teach the department to respond gradually to demonstration , rather than Body Text: advertisement domestic and international anger over israel ’ s response to the oct . 7 attack ha complicated president biden ’ s diplomatic and re-election effort . bymichael crowley nearly five month since hamas militant attacked and killed about 1,200 people in israel , president biden ha been swept into the resulting upheaval in the region . a he prepares to address the nation , he find himself navigating a wider middle east emergency with profound moral , political and security implication for his presidency . early sympathy for israel after the oct . 7 attack ha given way to domestic and international anger over the suffering in gaza . israel ’ s subsequent military campaign to crush hamas ha now killed more than 30,000 palestinian , according to official in gaza , with dire shortage of food , water and medicine creating a humanitarian crisis . because israel ’ s military heavily depends on american-supplied weapon and munition , mr . biden is under pressure at home and abroad to rein in israel and alleviate the suffering in gaza . but despite increasingly adamant call for israel to do more to protect civilian and provide them with aid , u.s . official say that is not happening . even so , mr . biden ha restrained his criticism of israel ’ s right-wing government and resisted demand for restricting american aid to israel , often reminding the world that israel wa brutally attacked and ha a right to self-defense . he ha ordered airdrop of aid into gaza to supplement the limited truck convoy that enter the territory from israel . but aid worker say those aerial supply will make little difference . seeking to do more , mr . biden will announce a plan for the united state to build a floating pier off gaza that can receive more supply . u.s . official say their best hope is to help broker a deal between israel and hamas to pause the fighting for several week , allow for the release of israeli hostage held by hamas , and enable a surge of humanitarian supply into the territory . some u.s . official think that such a pause in combat could evolve into a longer-term cease-fire . talk among several nation to strike a deal have been Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement the report will be presented to member of the security council next week and released publicly on june 18 , the u.n . said . byfarnaz fassihiandaaron boxerman the united nation will add israel , hamas and palestinian islamic jihad to a list of country and armed group that harm child when it release it annual report on child and armed conflict , citing the heavy toll the war in gaza ha taken on minor , including killing , maiming and starvation , u.n . official said . stéphane dujarric , the u.n . spokesman , said the body ’ s chief of staff called the israeli ambassador to the united nation , gilad erdan , on friday to inform him that israel would be listed this year . “ the call wa a courtesy afforded to country that are newly listed , ” mr . dujarric said , “ to give country a heads-up and avoid leak . ” hamas , the armed group that led gaza before the war , and palestinian islamic jihad , the second-largest armed group in the enclave , will be named in the report . hamas is being cited because it fighter abducted and killed israeli child when they attacked israel on oct . 7 , a u.n . official said . armed group that harm child in conflict , like the taliban and boko haram , are routinely named in the annual report . the news of israel ’ s listing further strained an already deteriorating relationship between it and the united nation . mr . erdan called the move “ an immoral decision that aid terrorism and reward terrorist . ” he made a video recording of the phone call andreleased part of it on the social medium site x . mr . dujarric , the u.n . spokesman , called the release of a recording of the telephone call “ shocking and unacceptable and something i ’ ve never seen in my 25 year serving this organization . ” the united nation ’ special representative for child and armed conflict prepares the yearly report under a mandate from the general assembly and the security council . the report will be presented to member of the council next friday and released publicly on june 18 , mr . dujarric said . the council will have an open debate about the report ’ s finding later this month . during hamas ’ s terrorist attack on oct . 7 , armed men kidnapped child , some of them toddler and baby , and held them hostage in gaza . child were also among the roughly 1,200 israeli and foreigner killed . israel ’ s retaliatory bombing campaign and ground war in gaza ha killed at least 36,000 people , gazan health official say , a large portion of them woman and child . the united nation ha said that child in gaza also face famine and starvation because israel ha restricted humanitarian aid . many child have also lost limb or been gravely wounded in other way . majed bamya , the palestinian deputy ambassador to the united nation , said in a post on x , “ israeli minister are the only one surprised of such a development ( list will be released next week ) after the killing and maiming of so many palestinian child . ” farnaz fassihiis the united nation bureau chief for the time , leading coverage of the organization , and also cover iran and the shadow war between iran and israel . she is based in new york.more about farnaz fassihi aaron boxermanis a time reporting fellow with a focus on international news.more about aaron boxerman advertisement

than a murmur , and forbidden to stand or sleep except when authorized . a few knelt in prayer . one wa being inspected by a paramedic . another wa briefly allowed to remove his handcuff to wash briefly see part of the detention facility a well a to interview it commander and other official , on condition of preserving their anonymity . once an obscure barrack , sde teiman is now a makeshift Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement supported by palestinian and israeli official offered differing account of a deadly scene in northern gaza , in which local health official said more than 100 people were killed . byhiba yazbekandaaron boxerman israeli force opened fire on thursday a a crowd gathered near a convoy of aid truck in gaza city in a chaotic scene in which score were killed and injured , according to gazan official and the israeli military , which attributed most of the death to a stampede . although official from both side offered differing account , the death of so many people who were surrounding a convoy carrying food in a part of gaza where starvation is rampant reflected the desperation and spiraling lawlessness in the territory following israel ’ s ground invasion and threatened to derail ongoing cease-fire talk . the gazan health ministry said in a statement that israeli force had killed more than 100 people and had injured 700 others in a “ massacre , ” a they waited for food from the convoy . the latest bloodshed came a gaza ’ s health official reported that the death toll from the war had risen above 30,000 , a grim milestone that intensified pressure on israel to end it military offensive . transcript thousand of desperately hungry civilian in northern gaza gathered on the street before dawn on thursday , hoping to find food on a humanitarian convoy . instead , hundred were killed and injured trying to get aid from the truck , according to gazan health official . local hospital staff said score were killed or wounded by gunfire . the israel defense force claim that most of the victim were trampled or run over by vehicle , and that their soldier only fired at a group of people who were threatening their force . israeli official declined to provide unedited footage of the incident . the fragment of drone footage they released only add to the confusion around the series of event that killed and wounded so many gazans . i.d.f . footage show hundred of civilian surrounding aid truck on the coastal al-rashid road in gaza city . throng of people crowd around each truck , hoping to catch bag of food a they are tossed off the back . at one point , people in the crowd suddenly appear to panic and run in multiple direction . the i.d.f . say that this footage show a mass stampede where gazans are trampled , but the quality and short length of the clip make it difficult to confirm these claim . another clip in the i.d.f . footage show two israeli tank a quarter-mile down the road and at least a dozen body lying nearby . the video doesn ’ t show the event that caused the casualty , but several people can be seen crawling and ducking for cover . other video , filmed from a side street by an al jazeera camera crew , help fill in some of the gap about what unfolded on the ground . it capture shot fired a crowd of people scatter and take cover . it is not clear when this footage wa filmed in relation to the i.d.f . drone video , but what is clearly visible is tracer ammunition , a specialized type of projectile that ignites to illuminate it path , which help troop fine-tune their targeting . the source of the fire is not captured in the footage , but the trajectory show it ’ s coming from the direction where israeli military vehicle are positioned , just a half-mile away . an israeli military spokesman , rear adm . daniel hagari , said that israeli soldier fired warning shot in the air before firing “ only in face of danger when the mob moved in a manner which endangered them . ” we are might be forgiven for thinking her guest are seeking a refuge . except form . meloni herself , every one of the leader is arriving at the meeting beleaguered , embattled or endangered — an ill-starred convergence that speaks to the political tremor rattling across the west . it also doesn ’ t bode well for the result of a gathering that already faced vexing challenge , ranging from russia ’ s war in ukraine to china ’ s global economic competition . britain ’ s prime minister , rishi sunak , is three week away from an election in which his conservative party is expected to beswept out of power . president emmanuel macron of france hascalled a snap parliamentary electionafter his party suffered heavy loss to the far right in european election . chancellor olaf scholz of germany and his social democratic party werehumbled in those election a well , while president biden isin a dogfightwith his predecessor , former president donald j . trump . even prime minister fumio kishida of in office , spoke for his fellow leader when he lamented the surge of populism in europe and the united state . “ we have seen around the world a rise of populist right-wing force in just about every Body Text: critic ’ s notebook the character known a handala , created by naji al-ali in 1969 , is making an imprint on art and a a protest symbol . columbia student occupying hamilton hall — which they renamed hind ’ s hall — in april unfurled a banner with the palestinian cartoon character handala , a boy with his back turned.credit . . . bing guan for the new york time supported by byaruna d ’ souza when pro-palestinian student protester took over hamilton hall at columbia university last month and renamed it “ hind ’ s hall , ” thebannerthey unfurled contained image of a cartoon character created over 50 year ago that symbolizes the resilience of palestinian . on either side of the text were two image of a barefoot boy with tattered clothes and spiky hair , his back turned to u . the character is called handala ( variously transliterated a hanzala or handzala ) , a name derived from a native plant that is deep-rooted , persistent and bear bitter fruit , and ha become a potent symbol of the palestinian struggle . the image wa created by thepalestinian political cartoonist naji al-aliin 1969 , one of the most widely read cartoonist in the arab world , who wa murdered in london in 1987 . ( the case remains unsolved . ) handala is 10 year old , the same age that ali wa when he became a refugee in 1948 . after the arab-israeli war of 1973 , also known a the yom kippur war , ali exclusively depicted handala with his back turned , a gesture that transformed him into a silent witness of the horror and outrage going on around him . the stance , according to the cartoonist , represented a rejection of the political machination of foreign nation when it came to the fate of ordinary palestinian . margaret olin , a religious study scholar at the yale divinity school and co-author of “ the bitter landscape of palestine , ” ha been photographing handala ’ s appearance in mural and a graffiti during her visit to the gaza strip and the west bank over the past decade . “ it ’ s become a symbol of the whole palestinian movement to return to their former home , ” she said in a telephone interview . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in reader mode please exit andlog intoyour time account , orsubscribefor all of the time . thank you for your patience while we verify access . already a subscriber ? log in . want all of the time ? subscribe . advertisement

three european country announced they wouldrecognize a palestinian state ; and israel backed down on seizing equipment from the associated press after an international backlash . but israeli leader are lookingfirst and foremost to their public , which , analyst say , still view the war with hamas in gaza a an existential conflict . while international support for israel ha eroded over it devastating military response in gaza — with over 35,000 people dead , according to health authority there — israeli have largely remained focused on the brutality of the hamas-led oct . 7 attack and the fate of hostage taken that day . political analyst say that mr . netanyahu hope to leverage the rising international criticism to tamp down frustration at home over his failure to either decisively defeat hamas or bring home the remaining hostage in gaza . some of mr . netanyahu ’ s key rival rallied to his defense on monday after mr . khan announced that he would seek a warrant for his arrest . “ israel is not only isolated , but feel that it is under some kind of siege , ” said alon pinkas , a former israeli diplomat . for many israeli , memory ofthe massacre in southern israel — in which roughly 1,200 people were killed and 250 taken hostage , according to the israeli authority — remain a constant backdrop to the conflict . month later , israeli news medium still continually air the story of victim , survivor and the family of those held hostage in gaza . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in reader mode please exit andlog intoyour time account , orsubscribefor all of the time . thank you for your patience while we verify access . already a subscriber ? log in . want all of the time ? subscribe . advertisement

Body Text: advertisement bythomas l . friedman opinion columnist the decision by spain , norway and ireland on wednesday to recognize an independent palestinian state mark the latest brick in the wall of rejection being built around israel ’ s current far-right government , which is asking the world to let it destroy hamas in gaza while refusing to work on a new future with non-hamas palestinian . more than140 country and the holy seehave recognized the right of palestinian to have a state in the west bank , gaza and east jerusalem . what is noteworthy about this latest move , though , is that major western european country , and the united state , had resisted going there , arguing that peace should be worked out between the two party . until today . my focus is always on the practical : will these recognition of a nonexistent palestinian state with undefined border lead to the only sustainable solution — a real-life peace between two state for two indigenous community — jew and palestinian ? the answer is yes and no . in the short term , these diplomatic recognition from fellow democracy will not move the israeli public , yohanan plesner , president of the israel democracy institute , told me . in the wake of the horrific murder , rape and kidnapping perpetrated by hamas on oct . 7 , he said , european telling israel that it must accept a palestinian state — “ without even mentioning that it must be demilitarized or any obligation on the part of palestinian to reject hamas ” — will be “ rejected ” by the israeli silent majority . in the long term , though , it is precisely these kind of diplomatic shock that could lead the opposition leader in israel to finally escape from the gravitational pull of prime minister benjamin netanyahu — who dominates what is or is not permissible to say on this subject — and start calling for two state on term israel can live with . one can already see sign of that . if that doe not transpire , though , israel is heading for a world of hurt . those recognition of a palestinian state by european nation “ are a huge straw in the wind , that will grow into a hurricane if israel doe not change course , ” craig charney , a pollster who wa a member of nelson mandela ’ s polling team in the 1990s , told me . charney explained that the isolation of south africa ’ s apartheid regime started with a voluntary arm embargo in the 1960s , which after the soweto uprising morphed in the 1970s into a formal u.n . arm embargo , which grew into a popular cause on campus and in boardroom in the early 1980s , which grew into a broader economic , military and travel embargo in the mid-1980s — until two great leader , nelson mandela and f.w . de klerk , finally emerged to end apartheid . “ but it wa a very painful journey , ” he said . thomas l . friedman is the foreign affair opinion columnist . he joined the paper in 1981 and ha won three pulitzer prize . he is the author of seven book , including “ from beirut to jerusalem , ” which won the national book award . @ tomfriedman•facebook advertisement

andrey kozlov , 27 ; and shlomi ziv , 41 , from the home of abdallah aljamal , the military said . a fourth hostage , noa argamani , 26 , wa also freed , apparently from a nearby building . more than 274 people were killed during the raid , according to gaza ’ s health ministry . the israeli military said that the death toll wa less than 100 . neither the israeli military nor palestinian health official provided a breakdown of civilian and combatant killed in the raid . mr . aljamal ’ s death wa confirmed by gaza ’ s government medium office on sunday , which said he had worked for the hamas-affiliated news agency , palestine now . on sunday , the israeli military said in a statement on the telegram messaging app : “ the hostage were held captive by abdallah aljamal and member of his family in their home . this isfurther evidenceof the deliberate use of civilian home and building by the hamas terrorist organization to hold israeli hostage captive in the gaza strip . ” israel ’ s military ha said for month that civilian casualty in gaza are inevitable because hamas hide it force within the population . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in reader mode please exit andlog intoyour time account , orsubscribefor all of the time . thank you for your patience while we verify access . already a subscriber ? log in . want all of the time ? subscribe . advertisement

Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement supported by fifa said it would solicit legal advice before taking up a motion from the palestinian football association to suspend israel over it action in gaza and the west bank . bytariq panja reporting from bangkok fifa , soccer ’ s global governing body , on friday postponed a decision to temporarily suspend israel over it action during the conflict in gaza , and in the west bank , saying it needed to solicit legal advice before taking up a motion submitted by the palestinian football association . the motion calling for israel ’ s suspension referred to “ international law violation committed by the israeli occupation in palestine , particularly in gaza , ” and cited violation of fifa ’ s human right and discrimination statute . responding toemotionally charged addressesat fifa ’ s annual congress by the head of the palestinian soccer body , jibril rajoub , fifa ’ s president , gianni infantino , said the urgency of the situation meant he would convene an extraordinary meeting of fifa ’ s top board on july 25 . before that meeting , he said , fifa will ask expert to analyze whether israel ’ s action breach the governing body ’ s regulation . by contrast , in 2022 , fifa acted quicklyto bar russian team and clubsfrom competition after the country ’ s force launched a full-scale invasion of neighboring ukraine . mr . rajoub ha for year pursued sanction against israel and it team over a variety of issue , including freedom of movement for palestinian player and for allowing team based in territory overseen by the palestinian soccer federation to play in israel ’ s domestic league . since israeli force invaded gaza last october in retaliation for the hamas-led attack on oct . 7 , all soccer infrastructure in the territory , including a historic stadium , ha been destroyed , mr . rajoub said . israel ’ s soccer chief , moshe zuares , called the palestinian motion “ cynical . ” but the possibility of even a temporary ban on it team could have immediate consequence : israel is set to compete in the men ’ s tournament at the paris olympics around the time of the fifa meeting in july , and to begin qualifying for the 2026 men ’ s world cup later this year . both israeli and palestinian official had used the run-up to friday ’ s congress to lobby official from other national federation . a day earlier , at a meeting of asian soccer ’ s governing body , memberswere shown a videoshowing the effect of the war in gaza and then unanimously approved a decision to back the palestinian federation ’ s motion . palestinian official addressed fifa ’ s 211 member twice during friday ’ s meeting , and were followed by an official from jordan who demanded action from fifa . while acknowledging the urgency of the matter , mr . infantino declined to call a vote . instead , he said , the organization ’ s 37-member governing council would decide what to do in two month . “ fifa will mandate a of now an independent legal expertise to assess the three request made by the palestinian football association and make sure that the status and regulation of fifa are applied in the correct way , ” he said . tariq panjais a global sport correspondent , focusing on story where money , geopolitics and crime intersect with the sport world.more about tariq panja advertisement
title: soccer ’ s governing body delay vote on palestinian call to bar israel

Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement supported by the security council endorsed a u.s . - backed plan , while secretary of state antony j . blinken visited the middle east to lobby for it , but hamas and israel were noncommittal . transcript “ 14 vote in favor , zero vote against , one abstention . the draft resolution ha been adopted a resolution 2735 . ” “ colleague , the cease-fire deal would pave the way toward an enduring cessation of hostility and a better future for all . a president biden acknowledged just the other day , the palestinian people have endured sheer hell in this war started by hamas . there ’ s an opportunity to chart a different course . ” byfarnaz fassihi , michael crowley , mike ivesandthomas fuller the united nation security council on monday adopted a u.s . - backed cease-fire plan for the gaza strip with only russia abstaining , a sign of the growing frustration among the world ’ s major power over the war and the desire to bring it to an end . linda thomas-greenfield , the u.s . ambassador to the united nation , told member of the security council that israel had already agreed to the deal laid out in the resolution — although israel ha so far resisted taking a public position on it — and she urged hamas “ to do the same . ” “ hamas can now see that the international community is united , united behind a deal that will save life and help palestinian civilian in gaza start to rebuild and heal , ” m . thomas-greenfield said . the 14-0 vote may strengthen the hand of secretary of state antony j . blinken , who returned to the middle east on monday to press hamas and israel to agree to a cease-fire . but in a sign of the difficulty facing mr . blinken and other mediator in achieving a final deal , israel ’ s representative to the u.n . , reut shapir ben-naftaly , did not say that israel had accepted the term of the cease-fire plan . she said that her country ’ s goal in the war had not changed and that it would use military operation to free hostage , a it did just two day ago . “ we will continue until all of the hostage are returned and hamas ’ s military capability are dismantled , ” m . shapir ben-naftaly told the council . she said if hamas leader freed all hostage and turned themselves in , “ not one shot would be fired . ” we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in reader mode please exit andlog intoyour time account , orsubscribefor all of the time . thank you for your patience while we verify access . already a subscriber ? log in . want all of the time ? subscribe . advertisement

Body Text: advertisement supported by “ just because you have the right to say something doesn ’ t mean it ’ s right to say , ” said carol christ , who is retiring a chancellor at the end of this month . bykurt streeter reporting from the university of california , berkeley . wave of boo , angry chant and the steady rhythm of foot pounding on metal seat were upending the graduation ceremony at the university of california , berkeley . “ viva , viva palestina ! ” student sang out . “ hey , hey , ho , ho , israel ’ s apartheid ha got to go ! ” it wa the soundtrack of this year ’ s antiwar protest , voiced on the morning of may 11 by hundred of cap-and-gowned graduate , loud enough to nearly drown out the ceremony ’ s official speaker — and force the event to halt . one minute passed . two minute . five . it looked like berkeley ’ s 2024 commencement wa about to be canceled midstream . then , suddenly , surprisingly , the ceremony resumed . once it wa over and most had left the school ’ s low-slung football stadium , berkeley ’ s chancellor , carol christ , sat near the podium in a folding chair . she is silver-haired and soft-spoken , a soon-to-retire 80-year-old former english professor with an unusual background for the modern college president : her view on free speech first crystallized during her year a a student protester in the turbulent 1960s . when the demonstrator forced the pause , had she considered ending the event ? “ absolutely not , ” dr . christ said . this is berkeley , she said . “ we were always going to power through . protest is part of our core . ” dr . christ ( her name rhyme with “ wrist ” ) plan to retire at the end of june . the first woman appointed to the job , she leaf a the oldest chancellor in berkeley history , and one of the oldest leader of an elite college campus in america . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in reader mode please exit andlog intoyour time account , orsubscribefor all of the time . thank you for your patience while we verify access . already a subscriber ? oct . 7 had been subjected to sexual violence , including rape . on tuesday , president isaac herzog of israelsaid on xthat the report wa “ of immense importance , ” and he lauded it for it “ moral that the report wa done “ thoroughly and expeditiously ” and that “ in no way , shape or form did the secretary general do anything to ‘ bury ’ the report . ” u.n . official alerted journalist in Body Text: advertisement the leader of northwestern , rutgers and the university of california , los angeles , appeared to have navigated their testimony before congress without many significant misstep . byjacey fortin the leader of three university denied that their campus have become “ hotbed of antisemitism , ” a one house republican described them in a congressional hearing on thursday . but they acknowledged misstep in the handling of the pro-palestinian demonstration that have engulfed american university in recent month , and said that some act of hostility toward jewish student need to be addressed . the hearing grew heated at time , especially a republican accused the leader of northwestern and rutgers of “ giving in ” to demonstrator . but for the most part , the president of the two school , a well a the chancellor of the university of california , los angeles , appeared to fare better than other university leader who have testified before the same committee since the oct . 7 hamas-led attack on israel . although they got caught up in some testy exchange and seemed to dodge a few question , the leader appeared to have navigated their testimony on thursday without many significant misstep . their response were at time considered , and at other time combative . they pointed to the challenge of balancing student safety with free speech — especially at rutgers and u.c.l.a . , which are both public university that must abide by the first amendment — and they condemned episode of antisemitism on campus . here are five takeaway from the hearing . the president of rutgers and northwestern said that the goal of striking deal with pro-palestinian protester had been to end the encampment and restore safety for all student , including jewish student who found the demonstration threatening . coming to agreement with the demonstrator had made that possible , they said — and noted that they had done it without committing to divesting from israel , a student had demanded . “ we had to get the encampment down , ” said michael schill , the president of northwestern university , adding that he had sought to avoid police intervention on campus — a decision that many of his peer have made , leading to nearly 3,000 arrest at university since april 18 . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . Body Text: a student in columbia ’ s class of 2024 received their diploma , many of them were grappling with what intense activism on campus would mean to their future . at barnard college , mariame sissoko , the student government president , began to question the value of always following the rules.credit . . . ahmed gaber for the new york time supported by byemma goldberg emma goldberg spent the week leading up to graduation interviewing more than a dozen student across columbia ’ s and barnard ’ s campus and attending their graduation . standing on the stage at radio city music hall , mariame sissoko began to speak in a voice trembling , ever so slightly . growing up in philadelphia , sissoko wa outspoken , a high achiever , captain of the high school debate team . in other word , just the sort of person who would go to barnard college , run for student government and wind up giving a graduation speech before an audience of 4,700 university official , classmate and parent . sissoko , 22 , who us nonbinary pronoun , had been warned by administrator not to deviate from the speech they had turned in week earlier . but that speech wa written before a pro-palestinian encampment sprang up on the main lawn of columbia ( barnard ’ s sibling school ) , before student occupied an academic building , hamilton hall , and the police made more than100arrests , before the campus became a locus of anger over the more than 35,000people killedin gaza during the war and of fear over risingantisemitism . now , on graduation day , sissoko put those warning from administrator aside . “ to stand on this stage today is a privilege , ” sissoko said . “ it is a privilege that over 15,000 child in gaza will never receive . ” sissoko ’ s classmate broke into applause . on sissoko ’ s lapel wa a poppy , meant to honor a 6-year-old palestinian girl killed during the war and a 10-month-old israeli baby taken hostage by hamas . “ i know that there are countless poppy with the name of child in gaza who have been killed , ” sissoko continued . “ they will walk across this stage with u . ” a sissoko paused , classmate seated in the audience began to sing an anthem that wa popularized during the civil right movement and that pro-palestinian protester at columbia had now taken up : “ we shall not , we shall not be moved . ” from the row of family seating came cry of “ boo ! , ” a chorus that grew louder a the student kept singing . an automated voice came over the loudspeaker : “ today ’ s speaker shared personal view , which may not reflect the view and value of barnard college . ” we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in reader Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement a the israeli military freed four hostage , the surrounding area came under heavy fire , generating chaos and panic , eyewitness said . bybilal shbair , aaron boxermanandadam rasgon a day after the israeli military rescued four hostage held by hamas militant in nuseirat , gazans described an intense bombardment during the raid , followed by chaos in the street from an operation that killed and wounded score of palestinian . bayan abu amr , 32 , wa carrying her 18-month-old son mohammad on the edge of nuseirat ’ s main marketplace on saturday when she wa surrounded by the heavy boom of strike from aircraft , which israel ’ s military said targeted militant in an effort to ensure the safe extraction of the hostage and special force . “ people were rushing like the day of judgment ; i did not know where to run , ” said m . abu amr , who wa on her way to pay a condolence call to her uncle ’ s family after two of his son had died . “ kid were screaming , woman were falling down while running . ” along with other gazans , she managed to clamber onto a passing pickup truck that wa trying to ferry people safely out amid the strike , she recalled . one girl wa separated from her mother in the confusion , while an old man lost his grip and fell off the truck onto the ground , she said . m . abu amr finally arrived home with her son hour later , shocked that she wa still alive . “ i won ’ t take my son out of the house again , ” she said . to rescue the hostage , israeli troop entered two residential building in which they were being held , according to rear adm . daniel hagari , the israeli military spokesman . admiral hagari said there were family living in the apartment , a well a armed hamas militant guarding the hostage , making it “ impossible to reach them without harming the civilian of gaza . ” we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in reader mode please exit andlog intoyour time account , orsubscribefor all of the time . thank you for your patience while we verify access . already a subscriber ? log in . want all of the time ? subscribe . advertisement

Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement subscriber-onlynewsletter what to know about karim khan ’ s decision to seek arrest warrant for three hamas leader a well a israel ’ s prime minister , benjamin netanyahu , and defense minister , yoav gallant . byamanda taub reporting from london the decision of karim khan , the international criminal court ’ s chief prosecutor , topublicly seek arrest warrantsfor the leader of hamas and israel this week will be one of the most significant and contentious of his career . khanaccusedthree hamas leader of war crime and crime against humanity relating to the oct . 7 attack on israel andhostage taking . he also accused israel ’ s prime minister , benjamin netanyahu , and it defense minister , yoav gallant , of war crime and crime against humanity during israel ’ s military operation in gaza , including thestarvationof civilian . now a three-judge panel will consider whether to issue the warrant . some country welcomed the news a a sign that all individual , regardless of their state or status , are equal before the law , while others — including the united state , israel ’ s most important ally — denounced the charge and accused khan of false equivalence in pursuing warrant for hamas and israeli leader at the same time . khan didn ’ t have to announce the warrant application publicly . he could have waited until they were granted , a with the warrant for president vladimir v . putin of russia last year — a process that can take week or month . so why did he go public now and with such fanfare — issuing not only anews release , but also social medium video and aprerecorded interviewwith cnn ? the answer lie partly in the extraordinarily polarizing nature of this conflict , in which any legal intervention would be subject to deep scrutiny . it ’ s also about what the prosecutor ’ s office hope to achieve a military action continues in gaza , famine loom and hostage remain in captivity . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in reader mode please exit andlog intoyour time account , orsubscribefor all of the time . thank you for your patience while we verify access . already a subscriber ? of thousand of jewish , muslim and arab student , are moving to offernew curriculum material about antisemitism and islamophobia . new york is one of nearly two dozen state that are required to teach student about the holocaust , andlawmakers included $ 500,000 in the state budgetthis year to review and update holocaust curriculum in school . the field trip program wa created by julie menin , a Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement a the muslim holy month of ramadan approach , the move may reduce tension at the aqsa mosque compound , which ha long been a flashpoint for unrest . byadam sella reporting from tel aviv the israeli government ha decided against putting new restriction on access to an important mosque in jerusalem during the muslim holy month of ramadan , a move that may reduce tension at a site that ha long been a flashpoint for unrest . at a meeting on tuesday night led by prime minister benjamin netanyahu , security official decided to let a similar number of worshiper enterthe aqsa mosque compoundduring ramadan a they had in previous year , mr . netanyahu ’ s office said . ramadan , whose start is tied to the sighting of the crescent moon , is expected to begin in a few day . israel ha long restricted access to the compound , which is sacred to muslim and jew alike , during ramadan for palestinian from the israeli-occupied west bank . this year , itamar ben-gvir , the far-right national security minister , called on the governmentto impose limit on arab citizen of israel a well . the decision on tuesday put an end to the plan promoted by mr . ben-gvir , but it allowed some wiggle room . “ a weekly assessment of the security and safety aspect will be held ; a decision will be made accordingly , ” a statement from the prime minister ’ s office said . the mosque compound ha regularly been the scene of violent clash . confrontation at the site in may 2021contributed to the outbreakof an 11-day war between israel and hamas . with ramadan nearing a the current israel-hamas war enters it sixth month , the fear of escalation at the site ha intensified . on tuesday , president joe biden said that if a cease-fire deal wa not reached by ramadan , “ it ’ s going to be very dangerous . ” mansour abbas , an arab israeli member of the knesset , the israeli parliament , praised the decision . “ i congratulate the prime minister for the responsible decision to allow muslim worshiper at al aqsa mosque freedom of worship , ” he wrote on x , formerly twitter . mr . ben-gvir , however , expressed concern that the decision would undermine israel ’ s effort to destroy the militant group hamas , which attacked israel on oct . 7 . “ hamas celebration on the temple mount ≠ complete victory , ” he wrote on x , using the name used by jew to refer to al aqsa . hamas previously condemned any israeli restriction on worship at al aqsa . on monday , a hamas leader called on palestinian to turn the mosque into a site of confrontation . palestinian in the israeli-occupied west bank and jerusalem should “ turn every moment of ramadan into a clash and confrontation with the enemy to protect al aqsa , ” osama hamdan , a hamas leader based in beirut , told a conference of muslim scholar by video . in muslim tradition , the prophet muhammad ascended to heaven from the site of al aqsa , and ten of thousand of muslim visit the mosque every day during ramadan . for jew , the area is revered a the temple mount because it wa the site of two jewish temple in antiquity that remain central to jewish identity . matthew mpoke biggcontributed reporting . advertisement

Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement supported by news analysis the proposal backed by president biden is deeply political and aim at stopping the war at least for now . but israel reject a permanent cease-fire and hamas ha it own reason for reluctance . bysteven erlanger steven erlanger , a former jerusalem bureau chief who ha spent many week in the middle east since oct . 7 , reported from jerusalem . even a hamas and the israeli government appear to be inching closer to a cease-fire agreement , analyst are deeply skeptical that the side will ever implement a deal that go beyond a temporary truce . at issue is a three-phase agreement , proposed by israel and backed by the united state and some arab country , which if fully realized could eventually see the total withdrawal of israeli troop from gaza , the return of all remaining hostage captured in the oct . 7 attack and a reconstruction plan for the territory . but making it to that finish line is impossible if the party are unwilling to even start the race or to agree on where it should end . fundamentally , the wrangling is not just about how long a cease-fire in gaza should last or at what point it should be implemented , but whether israel can ever accept a long-term truce a long a hamas retains significant control . for israel to agree to hamas ’ s demand for a permanent cease-fire from the start , it must acknowledge that hamas will remain undestroyed and will play a role in the territory ’ s future , condition israel ’ s government can not abide . on the flip side , hamas say it won ’ t consider a temporary cease-fire without the guarantee of a permanent one that effectively ensures it survival , even at the cost of countless more palestinian life , lest israel restart the war once it hostage are returned . yet after eight month of a grinding war , there are sign that the side could be moving closer to the first proposed phase : a six-week conditional cease-fire . while that step is hardly guaranteed , getting to the plan ’ s second phase , which envisages a permanent cessation of hostility and the full withdrawal of israeli troop from gaza , is even more unlikely , analyst said . “ it is wrong to see this proposal a more than a stopgap , ” said natan sachs , director of the center for middle east policy at the brookings institution . “ most important , this plan doesn ’ t answer the fundamental question of who rule gaza after the conflict . this is a cease-fire plan , not a day-after plan . ” we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in Body Text: middle eastcrisis advertisement here ’ s a closer look at the clash between israel and the lebanese militia hezbollah , which have raised fear of a broader middle east conflict . byeuan wardandmatthew mpoke bigg israel and hezbollah have traded fire across the lebanese border since the start of the war in gaza , with more than 150,000 people on both side of the boundaryforced to flee their home . but the intensity of the attack ha increased in recent day , leading to fear of a full-scale waron another front . this week , prime minister benjamin netanyahu of israel threatened further military action to ensure the return ofcivilians to community in northern israel . here are some key question about the conflict and where it might be heading : hezbollah , apowerful lebanese militia and political movement , launched attack into israel on oct . 8 , answering call by hamas to open a second front a day after the palestinian armed group that rule gaza led a deadly assault on israel . both hezbollah and hamas are backed by iran . hezbollah ’ s leader , hassan nasrallah , ha said that his group is trying to pin israel ’ s troop along the border and limit it capacity to attack hamas in gaza . hezbollah ’ s conflict with israel go back decade . israel ha invaded lebanon three time in the last 50 year , most recently in 2006 , when the two side foughta monthlong warthat killed more than 1,000 people in lebanon , mostly civilian , and more than 150 in israel , mostly soldier . the current round of fighting mark the most serious escalation since then . israel in february launched itsdeepest strikesinto lebanon in year , hitting the bekaa valley in response to a surface-to-air missile attack that downed an israeli drone over southern lebanon . we are having Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement supported by a pro-palestinian group slashed and spray-painted a century-old portrait of the author of the balfour declaration at the university of cambridge in england . bymarc tracy a pro-palestinian group slashed and spray-painteda century-old portrait of arthur james balfourat the university of cambridge on friday , defacing a painting of the british official whose pledge of support in 1917 for “ the establishment in palestine of a national home for the jewish people ” helped pave the way to israel ’ s founding three decade later . the group , palestine action , said in a statementthat the destruction of the portrait in trinity college , cambridge , wa intended to call attention to “ the bloodshed of the palestinian people since the balfour declaration wa issued , ” particularly in light of the current conflict in gaza . a spokeswoman for trinity , whose alumnus include king charles iii a well a balfour himself , said in a statement on friday that the college “ regret the damage caused to a portrait of arthur james balfour during public opening hour ” and that it had notified the police . a cambridge police statement said officer were on the scene to investigate a report of “ criminal damage . ” palestine action posted a video of a protester first spraying the portrait , painted in 1914 by philip alexius de lászló , with red paint and then slashing it with a sharp object . the group ’ s statement said balfour had given away the homeland of the palestinian — “ a land that wasn ’ t his to give away ” — touching off what it described a decade of oppression . since oct . 7 , when hamas militant invading southern israelkilled approximately 1,200 peopleand abducted 240 others , israeli bombing and invasion havekilled more than 30,000 people , according to gaza health official . defacing art ha become a popular protest tacticin recent year . it is perhaps most closely associated with environmentalist , who have targeted painting by van gogh , vermeer and monet . this year , two woman from an environmental group entered the louvre andflung soup at the mona lisa . most of the painting that have been targeted were covered or protected in some way , andvery few were damaged . in recent week , pro-palestinian protester have targeted art in new york . this week , a few dozen demonstrator disrupted the opening of an israeli artist ’ s show at a manhattan gallery , hyperallergic reported . last month , protestersinterrupted a conversationfeaturing an israeli artist whose drawing depicting oct . 7 are being exhibited at the jewish museum anddozens chanted “ free palestine ” in a demonstration at the museum of modern art . marc tracyis a time reporter covering art and culture . he is based in new york.more about marc tracy advertisement

Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement supported by the closure this month of the rafah border crossing into egypt , the only way out for civilian , ha thrown an already complicated system into disarray . byhamed aleaziz reporting from washington ghada redwan , a 48-year-old pharmacist in houston , ha been trying to get her parent out of gaza for month . their bag , packed and ready to go , have been sitting by their door in rafah , the city where israel is nowconducting a military offensive . but m . redwan ha hit roadblock at every turn . and like other palestinian american desperate to get their relative to safety , she ha described a confounding bureaucratic maze involving the state department , the government of israel and egypt , politician , advocacy group , lawyer and more . the closure this month of the rafah border crossing into egypt — the only way out for civilian — ha thrown an already complicated system into disarray , leading to call for the united state to make a more forceful effort to evacuate the relative of american citizen . “ you feel like there ’ s nothing you can do , ” m . redwan said in an interview . “ you live comfortably , you have money , you ’ re a u.s . citizen and your parent are suffering and there ’ s nothing you can do for them . it is just insane . ” m . redwan last spoke to her mother on monday morning , one day after an israeli strike thatkilled dozen of palestiniansin a camp for displaced people in rafah . “ there is no safe place , ” her mother told her . “ just pray for u . ” since the start of the war seven month ago , more than 1,800 american citizen and their family have left gaza with the assistance of the state department , u.s . official say . they are only a fraction of the hundred of thousand of gazans desperate to leave a the already dire condition there deteriorate . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your building wa one of several that made up the unrwa nuseirat boy ’ preparatory school . it wa one of the many school in gaza run by the main u.n . agency for palestinian refugee and their descendant . Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement israel ’ s military announced it had rescued four hostage who were held in gaza . there are roughly 120 captive still in the enclave . byephrat livni israeli briefly breathed a collective sigh of relief on saturday , when the military announced it had rescued four hostage who were held in gaza for eight month after being captured in the oct . 7 attack led by hamas . the four hostage were taken at the nova music festival on oct . 7 and were rescued in an operation in the town of nuseirat in central gaza early saturday . the mission left score of palestinian , including woman and child , dead . news of the rescue raised renewed question about the fate of those who remain in captivity and a proposed cease-fire deal . how many hostage are still being held in gaza ? roughly 120 captive remain in gaza . the israeli military ha confirmed that at least 30 of them have died . earlier this month , the israeli military informed the family of four hostage that they were dead and that their body were being held by hamas . in may , the military recovered the body of nine hostage , and the family of two thai citizen who had been captured were informed that their body were still being held in gaza . will israel undertake more rescue operation ? dozen of proposed rescue mission have not gone forward for fear the hostage or soldier would lose their life in the process , according to israeli defense official . israeli troop have managed to rescue only seven living hostage in three separate military operation . in december , israeli troop accidentally fired on and killed three hostage in gaza who were trying to reach safety . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in reader mode please exit andlog intoyour time account , orsubscribefor all of the time . thank you for your patience while we verify access . already a subscriber ? Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement an eight-mile-long strip of land between the gaza strip and egypt is the latest focus of the israeli assault on hamas . bymatthew mpoke bigg israel ’ s announcement on wednesday that it force had gained control over a strip of land that run along the gaza strip 's southern border suggested that it had fulfilled one of the goal of the country ’ s war against hamas , but it portends further isolation for palestinian in the enclave . here ’ s a look at the importance of the border strip to israel , to palestinian and to egypt : it is land around 100 yard wide that run roughly eight mile from israel ’ s border to the mediterranean . the new border , which divided the city of rafah , wa set up under the egypt-israel peace treaty of 1979 . to the northeast is gaza , while egypt lie to the southwest . egyptian border guard have been policing the land under an agreement with israel made in 2005 when israeli force withdrew from gaza . the israeli used the code name philadelphi for the strip , while egyptian official call it salah al din . senior israeli official had set control of the strip , which in israel is called the philadelphi corridor , a a military objective . hamas had dug tunnel beneath the strip — some wide enough for truck , according to military expert — and used them to smuggle weapon and personnel into gazan territory . “ this is the way they can get in and out without asking the israeli , ” said ahron bregman , a political scientist and expert in middle east security issue at king ’ s college in london , who is a former israeli military officer . unless the tunnel are blocked , he said in a previous interview , hamas could rebuild it military capacity after the war . during other regional conflict , egypt ha opened it border to refugee , but the government of president abdel fattah el-sisi fear that if palestinian civilian crossed the border to escape the war they could destabilize the country and become a drag on it economy . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in jerusalem in the month after he wa taken hostage in israel and hidden in the gaza strip , andrey kozlov ’ s captor kept drumming in the same message : the world , they said , had given up on him . even his family had moved on . “ your mom is on vacation in greece , ” the militant told him . “ your mom doesn ’ t know about you at all — and doesn ’ t want to know . ” so persuasive were they that when israeli security force burst through the door of the apartment where mr . kozlov wa being held on saturday , he wa at first unsure of whether they had come to save or kill him , his parent said in an interview this week during which they recounted his ordeal . the account of mr . kozlov ’ s eight month in captivity came a a doctor in israel reported that while he and the three other rescued hamas hostage seemed to be in fairly good condition at first glance , test showed that all were malnourished . and all , said dr . itai pessach , the head of the medical team for returning hostage at sheba medical center , had suffered mistreatment in varying degree of frequency and intensity . “ they were all abused , punished and tortured physically and psychologically in many way , ” he said . dr . pessach said the hostage he had examined had lost a lot of weight , though they gained some back , and their muscle were “ extremely wasted . ” the mix of poor nutrition , confinement , lack of sunlight and stress that they endured may have long-term implication for their health , he added . hamas say it ha treated the hostage well compared with israel ’ s treatment of palestinian prisoner , israel ’ s “ constructive approach ” to seeking a six-week cease-fire but urged the government to do more to allow desperately needed humanitarian aid to reach those in need in gaza . “ the vice president expressed her deep concern about the humanitarian condition in gaza and the recent horrific tragedy around an aid convoy in northern gaza , ” a white house description of the meeting said . Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement supported by the international court of justice ha no mean to enforce it order in the gazan city , but the ruling added pressure on the government of prime minister benjamin netanyahu of israel . bygaya gupta , aaron boxermanandyonette joseph the international court of justice on friday ordered israel to “ immediately ” halt it military offensive in the city of rafah in southern gaza , dealing another blow to the country a it face increasinginternational isolationand a drumbeat of criticism over it conduct in the war . the court ha few effective mean of enforcing it order , and it stopped short of ordering a cease-fire in gaza , with some of the court ’ s judge arguing that israel could still conduct some military operation in rafah under the term of their decision . but the order added more pressure on the government of prime minister benjamin netanyahu , who ha faced domestic and external call to reach a cease-fire deal with hamas that would lead to the release of hostage held in gaza . “ the court considers that , in conformity with obligation under the genocide convention , israel must immediately halt it military offensive , and any other action in the rafah governorate , which may inflict on the palestinian group in gaza condition of life that could bring about it physical destruction in whole or in part , ” the court ’ s president , nawaf salam , said in readingthe 13-2 ruling . the court , based at the hague , also specified the need for open land crossing , in particular the rafah crossing , a part of it request for “ the unhindered provision ” of humanitarian assistance and service . israel ha controlled the rafah crossing for more than two week , and very few aid truck have entered the enclave since , according to united nation data . the israeli government said in a statement that it military “ ha not and will not ” take action that would lead to the partial or complete destruction of the palestinian population of rafah . in effect , it said that the court ’ s decision ha no bearing on israel ’ s offensive because the prohibited act are not occurring . we are having trouble retrieving the article Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement the political divide over the israeli prime minister wa evident even in the announcement of when he would appear , with republican and democratic leader issuing separate statement . byannie karni reporting from washington prime minister benjamin netanyahu of israel will address a joint meeting of congress on july 24 , the top two congressional republican announced on thursday night . speaker mike johnson of louisiana and senator mitch mcconnell , republican of kentucky and the minority leader , said in a statement that the speech would offer mr . netanyahu the opportunity to “ share the israeli government ’ s vision for defending their democracy , combating terror , and establishing just and lasting peace in the region . ” but in a separate statement that hinted at the deep political divide over mr . netanyahu and israel ’ s war in gaza , senator chuck schumer , democrat of new york and the majority leader , said he harbored “ clear and profound disagreement with the prime minister , which i have voiced both privately and publicly and will continue to do so . ” he said he nevertheless had joined the request for mr . netanyahu to address congress because “ america ’ s relationship with israel is ironclad and transcends one person or prime minister . ” earlier this year , mr . schumer called for mr . netanyahu to step down and for israel to hold new election . the bipartisan invitation to mr . netanyahu , issued last month by the top four congressional leader with no date attached , masked a fraught behind-the-scenes debate over receiving him . the need for separate statement from the leader of the two party explaining their different rationale for extending the invitation underscored those tension . some progressive like senator bernie sander of vermont have already promised to boycott the speech , calling mr . netanyahu a “ war criminal ” for his tactic in the war against hamas , which ha killed ten of thousand of people in gaza and caused a humanitarian disaster . republican , in contrast , are eager to hug mr . netanyahu close and unequivocally back his policy . mr . johnson ha been the driving force behind the invitation . “ i am very moved to have the privilege of representing israel before both house of congress and to present the truth about our just war against those who seek to destroy u to the representative of the american people and the entire world , ” mr . netanyahu said in a statement accepting the invitation . annie karniis a congressional correspondent for the time . she writes feature and profile , with a recent focus on house republican leadership.more about annie karni advertisement
title: netanyahu is set to address congress on july 24

schwartz reporting from philadelphia a pro-palestinian encampment at the university of pennsylvania ha expanded , a student wrap up exam and the university finalizes it plan for graduation ceremony on may 20 . a post onsocial mediaby an account associated with the penn encampment said the expansion on wednesday night wa in response to “ the administration ’ s continued bad-faith negotiation ” over demand that the university divest from financial support for israel . steve silverman , a spokesman for penn , declined to comment on the activist ’ assertion that the university wa not negotiating in good faith . for nearly two week , the protester have been occupying the west side of a green space in front of college hall , the oldest building on campus . on wednesday night , after a march that brought a large group of student and philadelphia activist to college hall , protester expanded the encampment to the east side of the green space , moving the metal barrier that had been erected to mark the boundary of the protest space . penn ’ s administration ha largely taken a hands-off approach to the encampment . but on thursday afternoon , the university announced action against six student in connection with the “ unauthorized encampment . ” in astatement posted on penn ’ s website , the university said it had imposed “ mandatory temporary leaf of absence ” on the student pending “ disciplinary investigation . ” when asked on thursday about the protest , gov . josh shapiro of pennsylvania said that it wa “ past time ” for penn ’ s administration to clear the encampment . “ over the last 24 hour at the university of pennsylvania , the situation ha gotten even more unstable and out of control , ” he said , speaking at an unrelated news conferencenear pittsburgh . the governor , who is a nonvoting member of penn ’ s board of trustee , demurred when asked whether he would take independent action , saying that the matter wa best left to campus administrator and local police . on thursday , the scene around the encampment wa subdued . some protester rested on a plinth beneath a statue of benjamin franklin . others walked around the encampment with the chief of penn ’ s fire and emergency service , who wa surveying the ground for potential hazard . outside the barrier were small group of police officer , college administrator and pro-israel counterprotesters . this week , penn announcedspecial security measure for commencement , including no bag and “ airport-style security screening . ” advertisement

inclination to alter their stance . the growing fissure within europe mean that the consensus-driven european union will not change it position any time soon . but european country face rising international and domestic pressure to take a firmer stand against israel ’ s handling of the palestinian territory , and particularly the devastating war in gaza . sweden prominently became one of a handful of european union member to recognize palestinian statehood a decade ago . europe ha long supported the eventual creation of a palestinian state — the “ two-state solution ” that israel ’ s government steadfastly opposes — and voiced frustration with israel ’ s handling of the gaza strip and the occupied west bank , but most nation have been unwilling to go further . instead , the so many university . but cuny law student were also carrying on something of a graduation tradition at their school . student chanted pro-palestinian message , waved painted banner a they walked across the stage and turned their back to the law school ’ s dean , sudha setty , during her remark onstage at the apollo theater in harlem . then , after the last degree had been conferred , dozen of student rose from their seat and walked out , joined by a handful of professor and guest . “ it reminded me so much of why i came to cuny law , ” ale humano , one of the graduate who walked out of the ceremony , said . the walkout on thursday is not the first time that tension over israel have taken center stage during a commencement ceremony for the new york city public law school . the school , which is known for fostering public interest lawyer , ha been a hot spot for pro-palestinian activism for year , and it graduation ceremony have recently become the site of conflict over politics related to israel . for the past two year , law school commencement speaker have made support for palestinian and opposition to israel a focus of their speech , eliciting criticism from public official , who called the speech antisemitic . in 2023 , fatima mousa mohammed , a yemeni immigrant and an activist devoted to the palestinian cause , denounced “ israeli settler colonialism ” in her
