Body Text: for the first time since the vietnam war , university demonstration have led to a rethinking of who set the term for language in academia . a pro-palestinian protest on columbia university ’ s campus this spring.credit . . . mark peterson/redux supported by byemily bazelonandcharles homans emily bazelon is a staff writer for the magazine who also teach at yale law school . charles homans cover politics for the time . he visited the columbia campus repeatedly during the demonstration , counter-demonstrations and police action in april . early on the afternoon of nov . 10 , jameel jaffer , the director of the knight first amendment institute at columbia university , wa on his way into a meeting in low library , the domed neoclassical building at the center of campus , when an administrator pulled him aside . the school , the administrator said , wa about to announce the suspension of the campus chapter of the organization student for justice in palestine and jewish voice for peace , an allied anti-zionist organization — a move that alarmed jaffer given the fraught politics of the moment . the day after hamas ’ s brazen oct . 7 attack on military and civilian target in israel , the s.j.p . and j.v.p . chapter co-signed an open letter declaring “ full solidarity with palestinian resistance . ” the letter described the attack a “ an unprecedented historic moment for the palestinian of gaza ” and a “ counteroffensive against their settler-colonial oppressor . ” it would be tantamount to “ asking for quiet submission to systemic violence ” for anyone to call for peace now , after year of israeli violence and military campaign against palestinian . the group issued a list of demand to the university — divestment from company doing business with the israeli government , the end of columbia ’ s affiliation with tel aviv university and a recognition of palestinian “ existence and humanity ” — and announced a demonstration on oct . 12 on the step of low library . they signed off : “ see you thursday . ” the oct . 12 demonstration appeared to be in violation of campus rule , which required student group to give 10 day ’ notice for gathering in public space , but columbia had not been enforcing such requirement amid the emotional response to the hamas attack and israel ’ s retaliatory bombing in the gaza strip . “ we got some pushback from the university , ” recalled cameron jones , an organizer of the j.v.p . chapter , “ but not insane pushback . ” a the sit-in , teach-in and die-ins continued , however , that began to change . pro-israel group held counterdemonstration , and tension built on columbia ’ s small , enclosed central campus . “ in the past , demonstration were basically student protesting against the establishment , and that wa , you know , unidirectional and fairly straightforward , ” the president of columbia , minouche shafik , said in late may , in her first interview since december . “ in this crisis , ” she went on , “ student are opposed to other student , faculty opposed to other faculty . and those internal dynamic and tension have made this much more difficult than past episode . ” outside columbia ’ s library , several israeli student were physically attacked after they confronted another student tearing down poster of israeli held hostage by hamas . student wearing hijab and kaffiyeh reported being called “ jew killer ” and terrorist . by oct . 25 , when s.j.p . and j.v.p . staged a walkout of college class , “ our relationship with the administration wa really crumbling , ” jones recalled . two day later , israel ’ s invasion of gaza began . on the night of nov . 8 , with another demonstration planned for the next day on the step outside low , a faculty adviser told the organizer that they were out of compliance with school rule and asked them to postpone the event . theydid not , and the university suspended them . we are having trouble retrieving the article minister benjamin netanyahu on saturday reiterated that israel would not agree to a permanent cease-fire in gaza a long a hamas still retains governing and military power . in his statement , mr . netanyahu did not explicitly endorse or reject a proposed cease-fire plan that mr . biden had laid out in an unusually detailed address on friday . two israeli official confirmed that mr . biden ’ s proposal matched an israeli cease-fire proposal that had been greenlit by israel ’ s war cabinet . the official spoke on condition of anonymity to discus sensitive negotiation . but the timing of mr . netanyahu ’ s remark , coming first thing the next morning , seemed to put the brake on mr . biden ’ s hope for a speedy resolution to the war , which ha claimed the life of more than 36,000 palestinian , according to the gaza health ministry . “ israel ’ s condition for ending the war have not changed : the destruction of hamas ’ s military and governing capability , the freeing of all hostage and ensuring that gaza no longer pose a threat to israel , ” mr . netanyahu ’ s office said in the statement released on saturday morning . biden administration official and some israeli analyst said they believed that israel still supported the proposal mr . biden described on friday , and that mr . netanyahu ’ s statement on saturday wa more tailored to his domestic audience and meant to manage his far-right cabinet member , rather than to push back against the white house . mr . biden is eager for the war to end , with the american presidential election just five month away . but mr . netanyahu ’ s domestic political worry could prove paramount . on saturday night , two of mr . netanyahu ’ s far-right coalition partner — bezalel smotrich and itamar ben-gvir — threatened to quit his government should he move forward with the proposal . mr . ben-gvir labeled the term of the agreement a “ total defeat ” and a “ victory for terrorism . ” if both of their party left his Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement neither israel or hamas have said definitively whether they would accept or reject a proposal outlined by president biden , but sizable gap between the two side appear to remain . bymatthew mpoke bigg president biden raised hope last week when he endorsed a plan that he said could lead to a “ cessation of hostility permanently . ” he said israel had put forward the plan , but neither israel nor hamas ha said definitively that they would accept or reject the proposal , and they appear to still be locked in disagreement over fundamental issue . here ’ s a look at what is known about the cease-fire deal , which key point still must be negotiated , and the hurdle still ahead : israel and hamas agreed to a cease-fire in november that lasted for a week . but the proposal now on the table — a laid out by mr . biden , a senior u.s . administration official and israeli official — is more ambitious . major issue remain unresolved , including whether hamas would remain in control of the gaza strip . the proposalwould unfold in three phase . inphase one , among other thing , israel would withdraw from population center in gaza during a six-week cease-fire , and dozen of woman and elderly hostage held in gaza by hamas and it ally would be exchanged for hundred of palestinian detainee in israeli prison . during that time , talk over a permanent cease-fire would continue , and if successful , the deal would enter phase two , with the full withdrawal of israel ’ s military from the enclave . all hostage and more palestinian prisoner would be freed . under phase three , hamas would return the body of hostage who had died , and a three - to five-year reconstruction period , backed by the united state , european country and international institution , would begin . one of the key gap between hamas and israel over the plan is the length of the cease-fire and the future role of hamas . prime minister benjamin netanyahu of israel said on monday that he wa open to a six-week cease-fire , according to a person who attended a closed-door meeting he held with israeli lawmaker . but publicly he ha said that israel will fight until hamas ’ s governing and military capability are destroyed . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in reader mode please exit andlog intoyour time account , orsubscribefor all of the time . thank you for your patience while we verify access . already a subscriber ? log in . want all of the time ? subscribe . advertisement

kershner reporting from jerusalem for month , prime minister benjamin netanyahu of israel ha refused to offer a timeline for ending the war against hamas in gaza , a stance his critic see a a Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement supported by news analysis not on it own , in all likelihood . but it reflects a growing , global exasperation with israel that might eventually lend momentum to a two-state solution . byroger cohen reporting from paris the decision byspain , norway and irelandto recognize an independent palestinian state reflects growing exasperation with the israel of prime minister benjamin netanyahu , even from traditional friend , and suggests that international pressure on him will grow . it doe not , however , make it inevitable that otherlarger european stateswill follow suit . this year president emmanuel macron of france ha said such recognition is “ not a taboo , ” a position reiterated by the french foreign ministry on wednesday . in february , david cameron , britain ’ s foreign secretary , said that such recognition “ can ’ t come at the start of the process , but it doesn ’ t have to be the very end of the process . ” those were small step , although beyond anything they have said previously , but far short of recognition of a palestinian state itself . if europe were unified , with the major state joining in recognition , leaving the united state isolated in rejecting such a step , then it could have a greater impact , but that stage is far from being reached . “ this decision must be useful , that is to say allow a decisive step forward on the political level , ” foreign minister stéphane séjourné said in a statement about potential recognition . “ france doe not consider that the condition have been met to date for this decision to have a real impact on this process . ” france , in other word , will wait . so , too , will germany , whose support for israel , rooted in atonement for the holocaust , is second only to that of the united state . the decision of spain , norway and ireland ha made one thing clear : there will be no european unity , or at least aligned timing , on the question of recognition of a abstaining . the assembly broke into a big applause after the vote . but the resolution doe not mean a palestinian state will be recognized and admitted to the united nation a a full member anytime soon . the assembly can only grant full membership with the approval of the security council , and , if history is a guide , the united state would almost inevitably wield it veto power to kill such a membership . the resolution declares that “ the state of palestine is qualified for membership in the united nation ” under it charter rule and recommends that the security council reconsider the matter with a favorable outcome . the resolution wa prepared by the united arab emirate , the current chair of the u.n . arab group , and sponsored by 70 country . the united state voted no , along the tide of the war against hitler , president emmanuel macron of france spoke this past week of the “ bond of blood shed for liberty ” that tie his country to the united state . it is a bond that go all the way back to the founding of the united state in 1776 and the decisive french support for american independence against the british . tempestuous , often strained a france bristle at american postwar leadership in europe , the tie between paris and washington are nonetheless resilient . president biden ’ s five-day stay in france , an exceptionally long visit for an american president , especially in an election year , is a powerful testament to that friendship . but it illustrates it double-edged nature . french gratitude for american sacrifice a ever vies uneasily with gaullist restiveness over any hint of subservience . those competing strand will form the backdrop of a lavish state dinner at the élysée palace on saturday , when mr . macron will reciprocate the state visit that mr . bidenhosted for him at the white housein december 2022 , the first of his administration . the toast and bonhomie will not fully mask the tension between washington and paris — over the war in gaza , how best to support ukraine and the unpredictable way mr . macron try to assert france ’ s independence from the united state . no recent french president ha been a insistent a mr . macron Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement supported by some said the decision to seek arrest warrant for both israeli and hamas leader on war crime charge seemed to equate victim with perpetrator . byhiba yazbek , ameera haroudaandiyad abuheweila palestinian in gaza expressed mixed feeling after the chief prosecutor at the world ’ s top criminal court said he wasseeking arrest warrantsfor leader of both israel and hamas on war crime charge , a move that many said equated victim with perpetrator . “ we deplore , denounce and are surprised by the decision of the international criminal court which place the accused , the victim , and the executioner in one cage , ” said zahir essam , a 55-year-old living in gaza city . karim khan , the chief prosecutor of the international criminal court , announced on monday his decision to apply for arrest warrant for yahya sinwar , hamas ’ s leader in gaza ; muhammad deif , hamas ’ s military chief ; and ismail haniyeh , the movement ’ s qatar-based top political official . he also said he would seek warrant for prime minister benjamin netanyahu and defense minister yoav gallant of israel . the announcement in effect treated israeli official and hamas leader in the same way , despite what mr . essam see a a power imbalance between the two side in the conflict in gaza , which began when hamas led an attack on israel on oct . 7 . that attack killed about 1,200 people , and about 240 others were taken hostage , israeli official say . israel ’ s retaliatory war in gaza ha killed more than 35,000 palestinian , according to gazan health authority , though their figure do not distinguish between civilian and combatant . many palestinian view the oct . 7 attack a a justified response to israeli violation during the decades-long israeli occupation of palestinian territory . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in reader mode please exit andlog intoyour time account , orsubscribefor all of the time . thank you for your patience while we verify access . already a subscriber ? log in . want all of the time ? subscribe . advertisement

Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement the annual march celebrating israel ’ s 1967 takeover of the mostly palestinian east jerusalem ha long been a flashpoint . byaaron boxerman reporting from jerusalem ten of thousand of jewish israeli joined an annual nationalist march on wednesday through the heart of jerusalem to celebrate israel ’ s 1967 capture of the city ’ s eastern half , with some chanting extremist slogan calling for violence against arab . the rally , known a the dance of the flag or the flag march , ha long been a flashpoint for tension between israeli and palestinian , but security force were especially worried the event could spark violence this year because of the eight-month-long war between israel and hamas , and a steep rise in violence on the west bank . the march wind through jerusalem ’ s old city toward the western wall , one of judaism ’ s holiest site . chanting , dancing and waving blue-and-white israeli flag , the marcher made their way through the old city ’ s damascus gate into largely palestinian area of jerusalem ’ s old city . the marcher banged on the shutter of shop closed by palestinian owner who feared attack and chanted slogan that included “ may your village burn down ” and a biblical verse tweaked to call for “ revenge on palestine . ” the israeli police said they arrested 13 people “ involved in various violent incident ” in the old city . some of the israeli attending the march also hurled bottle and jeered at journalist from arabic news outlet , who were watching the area from a designated platform . officer later moved in after the bottle-throwing continued , detaining five more people , the police said . when asked about the violence against journalist , matthew miller , a spokesman for the u.s . state department , said : “ attack of that nature should be prevented when possible . when they can ’ t be prevented they should be fully prosecuted , people should be held accountable under the law . ” the demonstrator included many younger jewish israeli , wearing clothing emblazoned with the slogan of the religious right ’ s high school and military academy . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . Body Text: donald trump ’ s approach to the bloody mideast conflict reflects the anti-interventionist shift he ha brought about in republican politics — and his personal feeling about the israeli prime minister . donald j . trump ha pinned the blame for the entire crisis in gaza on president biden ’ s “ weakness . ” credit . . . haiyun jiang for the new york time supported by byjonathan swan , maggie habermanandmichael gold in the nearly five month since hamas terrorist invaded israel on oct . 7 , igniting the most divisive foreign policy crisis of the biden presidency , donald j . trump ha said noticeably little about the subject . he criticizedprime minister benjamin netanyahu of israel , before quickly retreating to more standard expression of support for the country . and he ha made blustery claim that the invasion never would have happened had he been president . but his overall approach ha been laissez-faire . “ so you have a war that ’ s going on , and you ’ re probably going to have to let this play out . you ’ re probably going to have to let it play out , because a lot of people are dying , ” mr . trump said in aninterviewwith univision a month after the attack . his main advice to mr . netanyahu and the israeli , he said then , wa to do a better job with “ public relation , ” because the palestinian were “ beating them at the public relation front . ” mr . trump ’ s hands-off approach to the bloody middle east conflict reflects the profound anti-interventionist shift he ha brought about in the republican party over the past eight year and ha been colored by his feeling about mr . netanyahu , whomhe may never forgiveforcongratulating president biden for his 2020 victory . mr . trump ha offered no substantive criticism of mr . biden ’ s response to the hamas invasion and israel ’ s retaliation in gaza . instead , he ha pinned the blame for the entire crisis on mr . biden ’ s “ weakness , ” in the same way he often doe when violence or tragedy occurs . “ you would have never had the problem that you just had , the horrible problem where israel — oct . 7 , where israel wa so horribly attacked , ” the former president told a crowd in rock hill , s.c Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement supported by news analysis a meeting between the british foreign secretary , david cameron , and an israeli minister , benny gantz , carried more weight than usual , analyst said , and stressed the frustration of israel ’ s ally . bymark landler reporting from london when benny gantz , a member of israel ’ s war cabinet , met david cameron , britain ’ s foreign secretary , in london on wednesday , he got a sharp message that israel must do more to allow humanitarian aid to flow into gaza . it wa the kind of minister-level meeting that would normally draw modest attention amid the flurry of high-level diplomacy that ha enveloped the israel-hamas war . but mr . gantz and mr . cameron are no mere functionary . mr . gantz , a former chief of staff of the israel defense force , is a popular political rival of prime minister benjamin netanyahu , and mr . netanyahu expressed deep displeasure at what he viewed a an unsanctioned trip by a would-be israeli leader . mr . cameron , a former prime minister , ha enjoyed uncommon latitude a foreign secretary , speaking out forcefully on issue like gaza and the war in ukraine on international trip , where he is often treated a though he were still in his old job . the unusual optic of the meeting — almost two shadow leader — speak to the peculiar domestic politics in each country . israel is in the grip of a devastating war that ha pulled mr . netanyahu and mr . gantz intoa temporary alliance . britain is in the twilight stage of an era of conservative-led government , with a prime minister , rishi sunak , who ismore occupied with a general electionlater this year than with foreign policy . for britain , diplomat and expert said , deploying mr . cameron to deliver a tough message to israel is valuable because it will register more than if it came from a standard-issue cabinet minister . it also spare mr . sunak the political risk of pressing mr . netanyahu directly and potentially being rebuffed . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement the u.s . secretary of state is expected to visit israel , egypt , qatar and jordan over three day . bymichael crowley reporting from washington secretary of state antony j . blinken plan to visit israel and three arab state next week , a the u.s . press for a cease-fire deal between israel and hamas to end the war in gaza . mr . blinken is scheduled to travel to israel , egypt , qatar and jordan from monday through wednesday , matthew miller , the state department spokesman , said in a statement on friday . the trip , which will be his eighth visit to the region since the oct . 7 hamas-led attack that set off the war , come at a particularly tense moment . the biden administration is trying hard to stop the fighting in gaza in hope of freeing israeli — and some israeli-american — hostage held by hamas and ending a conflict that ha exacted a grievous toll in life , physically devastated most of gaza and created political pressure on president biden to restrict u.s . arm delivery to israel . relation between the biden administration and prime minister benjamin netanyahu of israel are particularly fraught in the wake of mr . biden ’ s decision to hold up the delivery of american 2,000-pound bomb , a move meant to ensure that they are not used in the sort of “ full-scale invasion ” of the gazan city of rafah that mr . biden ha said he opposes . mr . blinken ’ s travel also come a worry are rising that fighting might escalate along israel ’ s northern border with the lebanon-based militant group hezbollah , which is backed by iran . the exchange of fire have prompted evacuation on both side of the border . a cease-fire would “ unlock the possibility of achieving calm along israel ’ s northern border — so both displaced israeli and lebanese family can return to their home , ” mr . miller ’ s statement said . qatar and egypt have each played role a mediator between hamas and israel , which do not negotiate directly . israel recently strained relation with egypt byseizing “ tactical control ” of a buffer zone on the egypt-gaza border , known a the philadelphi corridor . in jordan , mr . blinken is expected to attend a conference on the humanitarian crisis in gaza co-hosted by jordan , egypt , and the united nation . michael crowleycovers the state department and u.s . foreign policy for the time . he ha reported from nearly three dozen country and often travel with the secretary of state.more about michael crowley advertisement

Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement dozen of other displaced palestinian who had been sheltering nearby were also injured , the official said . transcript ( child scream ) ( screaming ) byanushka patil an israeli strike outside a hospital in rafah , in southern gaza , on saturday killed at least 11 people and injured dozen of other displaced palestinian , including child , who were sheltering in tent nearby , the gaza health ministry said . at least two health care worker , including a paramedic , were among those killed after the strike near the gate of the emirati maternity hospital , the health ministry said . photo taken by news agency showed colleague of the paramedic , whom the health ministry identified a abdul fattah abu marai , taking his body to the nearby kuwaiti hospital , a well a injured child lying on stretcher , a other child looked on and cried . the israeli military said later saturday that , with help from israel ’ s domestic security agency , it had carried out a “ precision strike ” against “ islamic jihad terrorist ” near the hospital . the military declined to respond to report that the strike had injured child . the israeli military had previously declared that rafah , gaza ’ s southernmost city , would be a safe zone for civilian , and more than half of the enclave ’ s entire population is now crammed into it , with many living in makeshift tent over nearly every inch of available space . butairstrikes on rafahhave continued even a the number of people sheltering there ha swelled to around 1.5 million . prime minister benjamin netanyahu of israel hasvowed that his force will invade the citywhether or not a temporary cease-fire deal is reached , despite dire warning from humanitarian group and many of israel ’ s ally that any military operation in rafah would have catastrophic consequence for civilian . the news of saturday ’ s strike wa “ outrageous and unspeakable , ” the leader of the world health organization , tedros adhanom ghebreyesus , said on social medium , reiterating call for a cease-fire and for the protection of health care worker and civilian . the victim of the strike were sheltering near the emirati maternity hospital , one of the last hospital still functioning in gaza . despite having only five bed remaining for woman giving birth , the hospital is managing more than half of the estimated 180 birth happening daily in the enclave , said dominic allen , the state of palestine representative for the united nation population fund , a sexual and reproductive health agency known a u.n.f.p.a . the emirati hospital is essentially “ the last hope for pregnant woman in the whole of gaza , ” mr . allen said . a strike so close to the hospital pose a “ terrifying ” risk to pregnant woman , newborn and the overloaded health care worker trying to care for them , he added . anushka patil is a reporter covering live news . she joined the time in 2019.more about anushka patil advertisement

Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement a commission produced the united nation ’ most detailed examination yet of the oct . 7 attack and the subsequent war in gaza . bynick cumming-bruce reporting from geneva a united nation commission investigating the oct . 7 attack on israel and the subsequent conflict in gaza ha accused both palestinian armed group and israel of committing war crime , and the panel said that israel ’ s conduct of the war included crime against humanity . in a report released on wednesday , the three-person commission — led by navi pillay , a former united nation human right chief — provided the most detailed u.n . examination yet of event on and since oct . 7 . the report doe not itself carry any penalty , but it lay out a legal analysis of action in the gaza conflict that is likely to be weighed by the international court of justice and in other international criminal proceeding . israeldid not cooperatewith the investigation and protested the panel ’ s assessment of it behavior , the panel said . the report said that hamas ’ s military wing and six other palestinian armed group — aided in some instance by palestinian civilian — killed and tortured people during the oct . 7 assault on israel in which more than 800 civilian were among the more than 1,200 killed . an additional 252 people , including 36 child , were taken hostage , the report said . “ many abduction were carried out with significant physical , mental and sexual violence and degrading and humiliating treatment , including in some case parading the abductees , ” the report said . “ woman and woman ’ s body were used a victory trophy by male perpetrator . ” the commission also reviewed allegation by journalist and the israeli authority that palestinian militant had committed rape , but it said that it had “ not been able to independently verify such allegation ” because israel had not cooperated with the inquiry . the report cited “ a lack of access to victim , witness and crime site and the obstruction of it investigation by the israeli authority . ” hamas ha rejected all accusation that it force engaged in sexual violence against israeli woman , the commission noted . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in reader mode please Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement supported by the investigation of prof . nadera shalhoub-kevorkian of hebrew university ha prompted a debate inside israel about the repression of free speech and academic freedom since the war began . bydamien caveandrawan sheikh ahmad damien cave reported from jerusalem and rawan sheikh ahmad reported from haifa , israel . nadera shalhoub-kevorkian , a palestinian professor at a prominent israeli university , first waded into the debate over the gaza war by joining academic worldwide in signing a letter that called for a cease-fire . it branded israel ’ s assault on the territory a “ genocide ” and the leader of her university responded byurging her to resign . that wa soon after the war began on oct . 7 . month later , the professor drew even more scrutiny for saying it wa time to “ abolish zionism ” and accusing israel of politicizing rape . she wa briefly suspended in march by hebrew university of jerusalem , where she ha taught law and social work for nearly three decade . but right-wing israeli politician demanded more severe punishment and in april , the police detained her overnight . “ i have been persecuted and defamed , my academic production of knowledge flattened and my home and even my own bedroom invaded , ” professor shalhoub-kevorkian , 64 , told the new york time . the professor is now under investigation for incitement to terrorism — a crime punishable by up to five year in prison . and though she ha not been charged , her case ha prompted a profound debate inside israel about the repression of free speech and academic freedom since the war began more than eight month ago . the professor ’ s lawyer say she is being punished for her political view . and some other israeli professor and student worry that the country ’ s university — which had long defended the value of relative diversity and open-mindedness — have contributed to the suppression of dissent . while university argue they are simply trying to keep campus calm , critic say there is a clear double standard across israeli society : violent rhetoric toward palestinian from jewish israeli is often brushed aside while palestinian citizen of israel who express support for palestinian in gaza or criticize the conduct of the war face discipline or even criminal investigation . we are having trouble retrieving the Body Text: advertisement supported by barnard college is requiring student to strip decoration from their dorm door in the wake of protest over the israel-hamas war . bysharon otterman dorm door decoration are emerging a the next battleground in the fight over academic freedom and free speech at barnard college . a at many school , barnard student often use their dorm door to display a bit of personality . a walk around the freshman dorm early this week found sorority pledge sign , lunar new year decoration and a pinned-up loose-leaf paper asking : “ who ’ s your celebrity crush ? ” but student had also posted sticker and slogan supporting the palestinian cause and naming the war in gaza a a genocide . “ zionism is terrorism , ” one student ’ s door sticker said . concerned that some student might feel intimidated by such message , the barnard administration ha decided to enforce a ban on dorm door decoration altogether . their removal wa set to begin on thursday , and all but “ official item placed by the college ” will be taken down , leslie grinage , the dean of the college , wrote in an email to student . “ while many decoration and fixture on door serve a a mean of helpful communication amongst peer , we are also aware that some may have the unintended effect of isolating those who have different view and belief , ” she wrote . barnard ha made aseries of movesto limit the space where student and faculty can express themselves publicly since the start of the israel-hamas war in october . the move are crafted broadly , but they come a barnard and other campus face controversy and litigation over pro-palestinian speech that some believe is antisemitic . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in reader mode please exit andlog intoyour time account , orsubscribefor all of the time . thank you for your patience while we verify access . already a subscriber ? official said , speaking without attribution to discus the sensitive operation . intelligence collection and analysis team from the united state and britain have been in israel throughout the war , assisting israeli intelligence in collecting and analyzing information related to the hostage , some of them citizen of both country , according to a senior israeli defense official familiar with the effort to locate and rescue the hostage . two israeli intelligence official said the american military official in israel provided some of the intelligence about the hostage rescued saturday . speaking in paris after meeting with emmanuel macron of france , president biden said he welcomed “ the safe rescue of four hostage that were returned to their family in israel . ” “ we won ’ t stop working until all the hostage come home and a cease-fire is reached , ” he added , “ and it ’ s essential . ” the pentagon and the c.i.a . have been providing information collected from drone flight over gaza , communication intercept and other source about the potential location of hostage . while israel ha it own intelligence , the united state and britain have been able to provide intelligence from the air and cyberspace that israel can not collect on it own , the israeli official said . jake sullivan , the national security adviser , celebrated the rescue , and referred glancingly at the american assistance . “ the united state is supporting all effort to secure the release of hostage still held by hamas , including american citizen , ” mr . sullivan said in a statement . “ this includes through ongoing negotiation or other mean . ” mr . sullivan added that the cease-fire proposal currently being discussed by negotiator from hamas , israel , egypt , qatar and the united state would be the way to bring home the remaining hostage . “ the hostage release and cease-fire deal that is now on the table would secure the release of all the remaining hostage together with security assurance for israel and relief for the innocent civilian in gaza , ” he said . american official have said their intelligence support for israel is focused on the location of hostage and information about hamas ’ s top leadership . in large measure this is because american official believe the best way to persuade israel to end the war is to get back it hostage and capture or kill top hamas leader . the israeli official said neither the american nor british team were involved in the planning or execution of the military operation to rescue the hostage . israeli , expert in hostage rescue , would have required little support in the tactical planning . but the american and israeli official said the outside intelligence did provide added value . julian e . barnescovers the u.s . Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement norway hosted the clandestine meeting in 1993 that led to the oslo accord , the framework for peace that came close to resolving the conflict . byemma bubola score of country have recognized a palestinian state , but norway ’ s announcement on wednesday that it would do so carried added significance because it hosted the clandestine meeting in 1993 that led to the oslo accord , the framework for peace that came close to resolving the conflict between israel and the palestinian . itultimately failed . norway call itself a friend of israel , and the two country have a longstanding relationship . but since oct . 7 , when israel launched a military offensive in gaza in response to hamas-led attack , norway ha also sharply condemned israel ’ s conduct of the war . norway ’ s foreign minister said in march that “ israel ’ s use of military force is having a disproportionately severe impact on the civilian population and is not in line with international humanitarian law , ” and called for a cease-fire . norway also continued to fund unrwa , the main u.n . agency that help palestinian refugee , after several other country stopped doing so following israel ’ s allegation that about a dozen of the agency ’ s employee had been involved in the oct . 7 attack . in february , norway testified at theinternational court of justice , stating that israeli settlement in the occupied west bank and east jerusalem were among the biggest obstacle to peace in the region . the oslo accord were landmark agreement that included mutual recognition between the government of israel and the palestinian leadership , which wa able to return to the occupied territory from exile . the accord also established the palestinian authority , which wa meant to be an interim body exercising limited palestinian self-rule in the west bank and gaza strip . in 2000 , continued negotiation toward a permanent peace treaty to establish an independent palestinian state alongside an israeli one dissolved into a second palestinian uprising and an israeli military clampdown . jonas gahr store , the prime minister of norway , said on wednesday that “ a recognition of palestine is support to moderate force that are on the defensive , in a long and gruesome conflict . ” he called the recognition “ an investment in the only solution that can give lasting peace in the middle east , ” and he urged other country to follow suit “ so that the process towards a two-state solution finally can begin again . ” emma bubolais a time reporter based in london , covering news across europe and around the world.more about emma bubola advertisement
title: why norway ’ s recognition of a palestinian state carry significance

Body Text: advertisement supported by some jewish student say they ’ ve been dropped by old roommate and sorority sister and ostracized from campus club and team because of their view — which are sometimes assumed . byjoseph bernstein last fall , a barnard college sophomore named sophie fisher reached out to her freshman year roommate to catch up over coffee . her old friend ’ s response wa tepid , and m . fisher wondered why . the two had been close enough that the roommate had come to the bar mitzvah of m . fisher ’ s brother . several month later , the reason became clear . over instagram , m . fisher ’ s roommate wrote to her that they couldn ’ t be friend anymore because she had been posting in support of israel since the hamas attack of oct . 7 . in other word , she wa a zionist . m . fisher thought she had been careful to avoid inflammatory post , but the roommate , m . fisher said , accused her of racism . then she blocked m . fisher . around the same time , m . fisher noticed something else strange . her “ big ” — a mentor in her sorority — had stopped talking to her . when they were in the same room , m . fisher said , the big wouldn ’ t make eye contact with her . m . fisher said that her big often posted about student for justice in palestine , the campus group that columbia had suspended in november for violating campus policy . m . fisher remains in the sorority , but the two haven ’ t spoken in month . “ she wa supposed to be my big sister , ” she said . this spring , college campus became the main stage for the american protest movement against israel ’ s seven-month-old war in gaza . in april and may , dozen of pro-palestinian encampment sprang up at university around the country , a student called for institutional divestment from ( and , at time , for the total dismantling of ) israel . the protest have been characterized by heated rhetoric around the term “ zionist , ” a word that typically refers to people who believe jew have a right to a state in their ancestral homeland in present-day israel ( regardless of how they may feel about the war in gaza ) . many palestinian and those who support them associate the word with mass displacement during the 1948 war triggered by the creation of israel , a well a the killing over the past month of thousand of civilian and the decimation of gaza . throughchants , statementsand sometimesphysical obstruction , many protester have made clear they don ’ t want to share space with people they consider zionist — and indeed , that they find the ideology unacceptable . at the university of california , los angeles , pro-palestinian studentsblocked peer who identified themselves a zionistsfrom part of campus . given that alarge majorityof american jew say caring about israel is an important part of their jewish identity , these instance of exclusion have led to a debate over whether the encampment are de facto antisemitic . ( complicating matter , some of the most outspoken anti-zionist protester are jewish . ) we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in reader mode please exit andlog intoyour time account , orsubscribefor all of the time . thank you for your patience while we verify access . already a subscriber ? log in . want all of the time ? subscribe . advertisement

determined to bring them home . for more than eight month , the militant have had the upper hand . israeli and american official say they do not know where many hostage are being held . and even when they do , in many case , a rescue mission is simply not possible . to date , israel ha rescued a total of seven hostage , but the stark reality is that since the war began , more hostage have died , Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement negotiator held preliminary discussion in paris this weekend , hoping to revive the possibility of a truce , the official said . bypatrick kingsleyandedward wong reporting from jerusalem and washington diplomat are aiming to restart negotiation for a cease-fire between israel and hamas at some point in the next week , according to three official briefed on the process , rekindling hope of an end to the fighting in gaza even a israel press ahead with it campaign there . according to the official , preliminary discussion were held this weekend in paris between david barnea , the director of israel ’ s foreign intelligence agency , the mossad ; william j . burn , the director of the c.i.a . ; and the qatari prime minister , sheikh mohammed bin abdulrahman al thani , one of the lead mediator between israel and hamas . the official spoke on condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the matter . for month , qatar , the united state and egypt have been trying to cajole israel and hamas into accepting a truce and an exchange of captive that could help bring the seven-month war to a close . but previous talk have repeatedly broken down over the length and nature of the truce : hamas want a permanent cease-fire , allowing it to remain in charge of gaza , while israel want to be able to continue fighting after a pause — so that it can wrest hamas from power . the other major point of contention in the last round centered on how to transition between different phase of a three-phase deal . previous sticking point have included the extent to which israeli troop should withdraw from gaza during any truce , and whether israel will allow gazans to move freely between north and south gaza . the side have also disagreed about the number of hostage that should be released by hamas , a well a the number of palestinian prisoner that should be freed in exchange by israel . in the last round , negotiator talked about hamas possibly releasing 33 hostage , mainly woman , the elderly and anyone in need of urgent medical care . more than 120 hostage remain in gaza , and roughly a quarter of them are dead , according to the latest israeli assessment . during the talk , egyptian and qatari official have dealt directly with hamas ’ s envoy , who do not meet in person with israeli or american counterpart . egypt took the lead in the last round of negotiation , which were held in cairo , though qatari official were also present . diplomat say that the hostage negotiation need to be completed in order to make headway in other related diplomatic initiative . those endeavor include a regional debate about who should govern a postwar gaza ; talk over a normalization deal between israel and saudi arabia ; and negotiation for a cease-fire between israel and hezbollah , the lebanese militia that is fighting the israeli military along the israel-lebanon border . rawan sheikh ahmadcontributed reporting from haifa , israel , andjulian e . barnescontributed from washington . patrick kingsleyis the time ’ s jerusalem bureau chief , leading coverage of israel , gaza and the west bank.more about patrick kingsley edward wongis a diplomatic correspondent who ha reported for the time for more than 24 year from new york , baghdad , beijing and washington . he wa on a team of pulitzer prize finalist for iraq war coverage.more about edward wong advertisement

Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement leader from the associated press , reuters and others called for the safety of the palestinian medium worker doing the on-the-ground reporting . bygaya gupta nearly 60 leader from international and regional news outletssigned a letteron thursday and friday committing their support for journalist covering the war in gaza and calling for their safety and the freedom to do their work amid intense personal risk . the letter , coordinated by the committee to protect journalist with the support of the world association of news publisher , also called on israeli authority to protect journalist a noncombatant , a required by international law , adding that those responsible for violation of that protection should be held accountable . “ these journalist — on whom the international news medium and the international community rely for information about the situation inside gaza — continue to report despite grave personal risk , ” the letter say of the palestinian medium worker doing the on-the-ground reporting . “ they continue despite the loss of family , friend and colleague , the destruction of home and office , constant displacement , communication blackout and shortage of food and fuel . ” the signatory include leader of the associated press , reuters , the new york time and regional outlet across africa , the middle east , europe and asia . palestinian journalist have faced grave risk or personal loss while trying to report on the war : some have been injured while reporting ; others have lost family member and colleague . several have quit amid the challenge . since oct . 7 , at least 94 journalist have been killed in the war , making it the deadliest period for journalist since the committee to protect journalist started collecting data in 1992 , according to the organization . israeli and egyptian authority have prohibited international medium from entering gaza , and journalist from other major news outlet have evacuated , making the true scale of the warimpossibleto grasp . according to data from the committee to protect journalist , most of the medium worker killed in the war were palestinian , and many of them were killed along with their family in airstrikes . some human right group have said that israel ha targeted journalist , though israel ha repeatedly denied that accusation . the letter prompted backlash from somejournalistswho said they or their colleague were punished by their news organization for affirming their support for palestinian journalist and civilian in letter highly critical of israel ’ s war tactic in gaza . when journalist haveresignedorbeen firedfor protesting the israel-hamas war , news organization have said that voicing opinion that take side violates their newsroom policy . gaya guptais areporting fellowon the live team at the times.more about gaya gupta advertisement

Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement president biden outlined a road map put forward by israel that would begin with an immediate , temporary cease-fire and work toward a permanent end to the war toward a permanent end to the war and the reconstruction of gaza . here are some of the detail , a described by mr . biden , a senior u.s . administration official who briefed reporter after the president spoke and israeli official who have discussed the possible deal . both side would observe a six-week cease-fire . israel would withdraw from major population center in gaza , and a number of hostage would be released , including woman , the elderly and the wounded . the hostage would be exchanged for the release of hundred of palestinian detainee . aid would begin flowing into gaza , working up to some 600 truck a day . hundred of thousand of displaced palestinian civilian would also be allowed to return to their home in northern gaza . most palestinian fled the north following israel ’ s mass evacuation order before the ground invasion began . during the first phase , israel and hamas would continue to negotiate to reach a permanent cease-fire . if the talk take more than six week , the first phase of the truce will continue until they reach a deal , mr . biden said . with a permanent cease-fire , israel would withdraw completely from gaza . all the remaining living israeli hostage would be released , including male soldier , and more palestinian prisoner would be released in exchange . it wa also unclear who would govern the territory under the agreement . hamas could use a cease-fire to reconstitute it rule in gaza . in the past , the united state ha said that the palestinian authority , which ha struggled to run the west bank , ought to be brought in to run gaza . israeli official , including mr . netanyahu , have generally rejected either the palestinian authority or hamas running gaza . hamas would return the remains of hostage who had died . rubble would be cleared and a three - to five-year reconstruction period would begin , backed by the united state , europe and international institution . jesus jiménez cover breaking news , online trend and other subject . he is based in new york city.more about jesus jiménez aaron boxermanis a time reporting fellow with a focus on international news.more about aaron boxerman advertisement

’ s war in gazahave sprung up at universitiesacross the country this spring , leading to more than 3,000 arrest since mid-april and heightened tension between student and university . “ to ensure the semi-permanent or permanent chalk or marker . penn ’ s administration said that the new rule , which will be reviewed by a faculty-led task force in the 2024-25 academic year , were issued in response to call for more clarity about what wa permitted on campus . the administration said that the rule “ aim to enable free expression while allowing penn to deliver it core mission of teaching , research , service and patient care without disruption . ” the university said that student who violated the rule would face disciplinary action , but did not go into detail . we are having trouble retrieving Body Text: israel-hamaswar after 50 year of failure to stop violence and terrorism against palestinian by jewish ultranationalists , lawlessness ha become the law . after 50 year of failure to stop violence and terrorism against palestinian by jewish ultranationalists , lawlessness ha become the law . credit . . . supported by byronen bergmanandmark mazzetti this story is told in three part . the first document the unequal system of justice that grew around jewish settlement in gaza and the west bank . the second show how extremist targeted not only palestinian but also israeli official trying to make peace . the third explores how this movement gained control of the state itself . taken together , they tell the story of how a radical ideology moved from the fringe to the heart of israeli political power . by the end of october , it wa clear that no one wa going to help the villager of khirbet zanuta . a tiny palestinian community , some 150 people perched on a windswept hill in the west bank near hebron , it had long faced threat from the jewish settler who had steadily encircled it . but occasional harassment and vandalism , in the day after the oct . 7 hamas attack , escalated into beating and murder threat . the villager made appeal after appeal to the israeli police and to the ever-present israeli military , but their call for protection went largely unheeded , and the attack continued with no consequence . so one day the villager packed what they could , loaded their family into truck and disappeared . who bulldozed the village after that is a matter of dispute . the israeli army say it wa the settler ; a senior israeli police officer say it wa the army . either way , soon after the villager left , little remained of khirbet zanuta besides the ruin of a clinic and an elementary school . one wall of the clinic , leaning sideways , bore a sign saying that it had been funded by an agency of the european union providing “ humanitarian support for palestinian at risk of forcible transfer in the west bank . ” near the school , someone had planted the flag of israel a another kind of announcement : this is jewish land now . such violence over the decade in place like khirbet zanuta is well documented . but protecting the people who carry out that violence is the dark secret of israeli justice . the long arc of harassment , assault and murder of palestinian by jewish settler is twinned with a shadow history , one of silence , avoidance and abetment by israeli official . for many of those official , it is palestinian terrorism that most threatens israel . but in interview with more than 100 people — current and former officer of the israeli military , the national israeli police and the shin bet domestic security service ; high-ranking israeli political official , including four former prime minister ; palestinian leader and activist ; israeli human right lawyer ; american official charged with supporting the israeli-palestinian partnership — we found a different and perhaps even more destabilizing threat . a long history of crime without punishment , many of those official now say , threatens not only palestinian living in the occupied territory but also the state of israel itself . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in reader mode please exit andlog intoyour time account , orsubscribefor all of the time . thank you for your patience while we verify access . already a subscriber ? log in . want all of the time ? subscribe . advertisement

Body Text: israel-hamaswar in safed , a center of kabbalah , ordinary citizen shocked by the oct . 7 attack are carrying military-grade weapon . prayer at safed old jewish cemetery this month.credit . . . supported by bydamien cave photograph byamit elkayam reporting from safed , an epicenter of jewish mysticism . eyal ben-ari tugged at the heavy assault rifle hanging over his shoulder a he tiptoed out of his pink house at sunrise , hoping not to wake his wife or six child . walking to synagogue in safed , a hill town above the sea of galilee known for century a a center of kabbalah , or ancient jewish mysticism , he said he still didn ’ t feel great about the gun . sleeping with the rifle under his pillow , he worried about it being stolen . after his 13-year-old son came home with a toy replica , mr . ben-ari considered returning the real thing , doubting his decision to join the newly formed civilian militia that had given him the weapon . “ i feel like it ’ s very — artificial , ” he said , struggling to find the right word in english , looking down at the gun . “ it ’ s not human . it ’ s not life . ” at the synagogue , men with graying beard and black suit — all fellow member of the chabad movement , an ultra-orthodox sect of judaism — slapped mr . ben-ari on the back . they were happy to see him . happy to see his gun . it wa the only one there , but far from unique . in this small city near the lebanon border , where hezbollah ’ s rocket have often rained down in recent month , israel ’ s deep sense of vulnerability ha led to a surge of citizen arming themselves . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in reader mode please exit andlog intoyour time account , orsubscribefor all of the time . thank you for your patience while we verify access . already a subscriber ? log in . want all of the time ? subscribe . advertisement

writes about weapon and military aid to conflict zone . an american-made , precision guided bomb that home in on specific target and , ideally , limit civilian casualty , wa used in airstrikes in gaza that killed dozen of palestinian , including woman and child . the weapon , the gbu-39 , or small-diameter bomb , wa used in an attackat a former united nation school on thursday and in amay 26 strike in rafah . in both case , the israeli military defended it action , saying the strike were aimed at militant using civilian a human shield . the gaza health authority said that civilian had also been killed , and there were video and picture of woman and child among the dead . two weapon expert told the new york time that israel ha appeared to increase the use of the bomb since the start of this year , compared with the war ’ s earliest day , when it launched them in only 10 percent of airstrikes against gaza . a a recent spate of israeli strike demonstrates , even a relatively diminutive bomb can inflict severe civilian casualty . “ the thing is , even using a smaller weapon , or using a precision guided weapon , doesn ’ t mean you don ’ t kill civilian , and it doesn ’ t mean that all of your strike are suddenly lawful , ” said brian castner , a weapon expert at amnesty international . early in the war , the israeli military mounted full-scale invasion of gazan city with tank , moved in . the protester then fled to an area by murphy hall , amassing about 300 people at one point , and then some eventually moved into dodd hall . in recent week , student activist have been mr . bowman may help win over jewish voter , a well a other moderate voter . “ a someone who is among the most popular democrat in the hudson valley , it is my prerogative to play a dispositive role Body Text: advertisement even before the war in gaza brought upheaval to college campus , the rutgers president wa criticized over his response to an instructor ’ strike and approval of a tuition increase . bysharon otterman when jonathan holloway , a scholar of african american history , wa appointed a the 21st president of rutgers in 2020 , he said one of his goal wa to foster “ a beloved community , ” a university culture defined by tolerance , diversity and the spirited exchange of opinion and idea . “ if ever there is a time when people need to be authentically listened to , it ’ s now , ” he toldrutgers magazineshortly after taking office . “ so , it ’ s important to me to be graceful . to grant grace . ” his goal ha been tested ever since . even before the war in gaza brought upheaval to college campus , dr . holloway wa under scrutiny for several unpopular move . thousand ofinstructors went on strike to demand better pay , leading dr . holloway to threaten a court order to force them back to work . he also approved a tuition increase and removed a popular administrator , thechronicle of higher educationreported . lastseptember , in a symbolic move , the rutgers university senate voted no confidence in his leadership following the month of tumult . the rutgers senate is a democratically elected group of faculty , staff and student ; it doe not , however , have the power to remove the president . this spring , dr . holloway decided to strike adealwith pro-palestinian demonstrator to end their four-day encampment at the university ’ s new brunswick campus . some charged that he had rewarded demonstrator after they disrupted campus life and chanted anti-israel slogan that some view a antisemitic . dr . holloway ha defended the agreement , even though he acknowledged that “ some of the statement that i have heard are disgraceful and have no place at a university . ” “ the result of our action wa a peaceful return to the normal course of business , ” he told the school ’ sboard of governorson may 6 . before becoming rutgers ’ sfirst black president , dr . holloway wa provost of northwestern university and a professor of history at yale for nearly two decade . at yale , he also served a dean of yale college . president holloway ’ s scholarly work focus on african american history after the civil war , and he ha published several book . one of his yale course on african american history is availableonline . sharon ottermanis a time reporter covering higher education , public health and other issue facing new york city.more about sharon otterman advertisement

gaza and the west bank , a well a the ongoing enabling of armed militia to terrorize palestinian in the west bank , do not benefit from new york state charitable tax exemption . ” assemblyman zohran Body Text: advertisement supported by critic ’ s notebook commencement is the rare american ritual that still ha rule . that ’ s why it ’ s ripe for disruption . byjason farago recycled robe , processional march , silver pen from tiffany : it is graduation season in america . may brings a nationwide festival of youth , with root stretching back to before the foundation of the republic , and though many college commencement this month have taken place under police surveillance amid student outcry , the ceremony have gone on . there are more than three century of precedent for graduation ritual — for it dress , for it speech , and for it disturbance . if commencement is ripe for contestation ( the back turned on the speaker , the kaffiyeh replacing the pointed sash ) , that ’ s because it ’ s one of the very last venue in which american show a commitment tohowwe do thing , and not just what we say and record . i am always a little surprised that university have hung onto these habit , almost uniquely longstanding . this is a country where very little endures . you can arrive at the met gala half-naked . you can play bach or beyoncé at a funeral . but graduation still ha rule . the student graduating from four-year college and university this month began their study , for the most part , in pandemic year zero . they missed , in 2020 , the walk across the football field or the auditorium stage to collect their high school diploma , and a the war in gaza continues to inflame campus some are facing disarray again . columbia university , which called in the new york police department to oust pro-palestinian student demonstrator , broke it universitywide commencement into smaller chunk . emory university moved it ceremony off campus . none ha been outright canceled , though . it take a lot to cancel a graduation . at harvard , wherehundreds of studentswalked out of this year ’ s main ceremony , outbreak of smallpox meant no commencement in 1752 , 1757 ( theseven year ’ wardidn ’ t help that year ) , and 1764 . revolutionary hostility canceled the commencement of 1774-78 and 1780 , but harvard would not miss a commencement again until 2020 . the ceremony took place through the civil war and two world war , and it went ahead in 1970 , after national guardsman shot and killed four student at kent state who were protesting the war in vietnam . ( demonstration did cancel graduation at boston university , hunter college and other school ; kent state ’ swas scaled down . ) in harvard yard that june , graduate protested the war by refusing to don cap and gown , or else by wearing white armband over their robe . local demonstrator with a bullhorn occupied the dais to demand low-income housing in cambridge . student heard dueling oration that denounced the nixon administration and student for a democratic society . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in reader mode please exit andlog intoyour time account , orsubscribefor all of the time . thank you for your patience while we verify access . already a subscriber ? log in . want all of the time ? subscribe . advertisement

Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement supported by palestinian have long gathered and cooked khobeza , a spinach-like wild plant that sprout after rain . now , it ha become a lifeline . byben hubbardandbilal shbair ben hubbard reported from istanbul , and bilal shbair from deir al balah , gaza . a theisraeli military campaignto destroy hamas pummeled his neighborhood in northern gaza , reducing building to rubble and forcing resident to flee , the palestinian laborer realized that he wa running out of food . the shop had closed , the market had emptied and fighting prevented supply from reaching them . so he and his remaining neighbor gathered a plant known a khobeza that grew near their home and cooked it to sustain themselves , he said . “ it supported u more than everyone else in the world , ” the laborer , amin abed , 35 , said recently by phone from gaza . “ people survived the darkest chapter of the war on khobeza alone . ” for many generation , the people of the holy land have foraged for khobeza , a hearty green with a taste and texture somewhere between spinach and kale that sprout in knee-high thicket along roadside and empty patch of dirt after the first winter rain . cook sauté it in olive oil , season it with onion or boil it into soup to make tasty , low-cost meal . now , this green , a variety of mallow , is making up an outsize portion of many gazans ’ diet by providing an inexpensive way to blunt hunger . at a time when most other food islargely unavailableor prohibitively expensive , gazans can harvest khobeza themselves and cook it by itself , or with a few other ingredient . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in reader mode please exit andlog intoyour time account , orsubscribefor all of the time . thank you for your patience while we verify access . already a subscriber ? Body Text: advertisement supported by the policy could ease pressure on the school to issue statement on current event . official were criticized for their handling of the oct . 7 hamas attack . byvimal patelandanemona hartocollis harvard said on tuesday that it would now avoid taking position on matter that are not “ relevant to the core function of the university , ” accepting the recommendation of a faculty committee that urged the university to dramatically reduce it message on issue of the day . if put into practice , harvard would no longer issue official statement of empathy , which it did for ukraine , after the russian invasion , and for the victim of the oct . 7 hamas attack in israel , for example . “ in issuing official statement of empathy , the university run the risk of appearing to care more about some place and event than others , ” the report said . “ and because few , if any , world event can be entirely isolated from conflicting viewpoint , issuing official empathy statement run the risk of alienating some member of the community by expressing implicit solidarity with others . ” the university ’ s institutional voice working group , made up of eight faculty member , issued the report , with a set of principle and a recommended path forward , which the administration and governing board accepted . “ harvard isn ’ t a government , ” noah feldman , a harvard law professor and a co-chair of the committee that developed the recommendation , said inan interview with the harvard gazette , released tuesday a part of the university ’ s announcement . “ it shouldn ’ t have a foreign policy or a domestic policy . ” the report , however , did not fully embrace “ institutional neutrality ” — a principle promoted by the university of chicago , in which university commit to staying out of political and social matter . some university , including stanford university and northwestern , announced shortly after the hamas attack that Body Text: advertisement supported by news analysis president biden ha promised to support the two country for a long a it take . both their war appear to be at critical turning point . bydavid e . sanger reporting from washington over the past five day , president biden ha been engaged in a very public demonstration of the struggle of managing two of america ’ s most difficult ally , president volodymyr zelensky of ukraine and prime minister benjamin netanyahu of israel , both leading country that the president ha vowed to defend , a long a it take . the conflict they are engaged in could not be more different , born out of grievance that reach back decade . but by coincidence , both confrontation seem to be at critical turning point , that moment when it becomes obvious how starkly national interest are diverging — to say nothing of the political interest of three leader clearly worried about their own hold on power . adding to the complexity of the problem , it is unclear in washington exactly what an acceptable endgame might look in ukraine or in gaza . officially , ukraine still talk about total victory , pushing russia out of every inch of territory it seized since the february 2022 invasion . israel still speaks of the goal of the “ total destruction ” of hamas , the only way to assure that it could never again mount an attack like the oct . 7 assault that killed nearly 1,200 israeli and sparked seven month of brutal retaliation . but in washington , those rallying call sound increasingly unrealistic . russia appears to be regaining momentum . the call for the total defeat of hamas sound like a rationale for perpetual war — and , in fact , israeli official have publicly declared the war in gaza will likely continue to the end of the year , if not longer . so mr . biden ha taken to crisis management , trying to prevent the worst , even if he can not answer the question of how , exactly , these war end . “ neither ukraine nor israel is a treaty ally , ” said aaron david miller , a senior fellow at the carnegie endowment for international peace and a longtime mideast negotiator . he wa referring to the status of the other 31 member of nato , which are obliged to come to one another ’ s defense , and the formal american pact with japan , south korea , the philippine and others . “ and yet we are fully invested in how to get these war to the next phase , a phase where we lessen the violence , even if we can ’ t articulate a realistic vision of how it stop . ” we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement it wa unclear if negotiator from egypt and qatar would participate . byjulian e . barnesandedward wong reporting from washington william j . burn , the c.i.a . director , who ha been the lead american negotiator in effort for a cease-fire in gaza , plan to travel to europe this weekend for talk with his israeli counterpart to try to revive the stalled discussion over a pause in the fighting and the release of hostage , according to a u.s . official and another person briefed on the negotiation . this month , frustration boiled over between official from hamas and israel , and the country mediating — the united state , qatar and egypt — put the talk on hold . israeli official were upset with what they saw a shifting negotiating stance by hamas , including the number of hostage to be released in a first phase . hamas wa upset by israel ’ s operation in rafah , the southern gazan city , whichhave been progressingsince . but core to the dispute were disagreement over how to define a cessation of hostility between hamas and israel , and how different stage of the cease-fire would be put into effect . the resumption of talk , at an undisclosed location in europe , is expected to take place over the next few day . it is not clear if egyptian and qatari negotiator will join mr . burn and david barnea , the chief of the mossad , israel ’ s spy agency , to directly take part in the discussion . mr . burn , however , ha been in close contact with egyptian and qatari negotiator a the mediator look to get the talk back on track , said a u.s . official . in early may , mr . burn did shuttle diplomacybetween egypt and israel trying to push for the first phase of an agreement to begin , including a staggered process for the release of hostage and a temporary halt in fighting . the talk in the coming day are expected to be the first since that round of negotiation ended . while it is unclear what could be achieved with mr . burn ’ s new discussion , restarting the talk is , at this point , a notable development . u.s . official say a hostage-for-cease-fire agreement ha to be reached for all their other diplomatic effort to get momentum , including discussion of a postwar administration in gaza and a megadeal for a palestinian state that the american and saudi want israel to agree to . but israeli military operation in rafah continue to complicate the picture . the more aggressive the israeli operation there , the less hamas want to negotiate . some american official have said israel is taking their advice on how to mitigate some civilian casualty — which ha contributed to an erosion of international support for israel with over 35,000 people dead , according to the gazan health authority . on wednesday , jake sullivan , the u.s . national security adviser , said he wa optimistic that israel , so far , wa not conducting the kind of major operation in rafah that the united state had feared it would . but question remain about exactly what the israeli intention for rafah over the longer term might be . julian e . barnescovers the u.s . intelligence agency and international security matter for the time . he ha written about security issue for more than two decades.more about julian e . barnes edward wongis a diplomatic correspondent who ha reported for the time for more than 24 year from new york , baghdad , beijing and washington . he wa on a team of pulitzer prize finalist for iraq war coverage.more about edward wong advertisement

transcript israel ha offered a comprehensive new proposal . it ’ s a road map to an enduring cease-fire and the release of all hostage . this proposal ha been transmitted by qatar to hamas . this is truly a decisive moment . israel ha made their proposal . hamas say it want a cease-fire . this deal is an opportunity to prove whether they really mean it . hamas need to take the deal . for month , point , hamas no longer is capable of carrying out another oct . 7 . and the palestinian people have endured sheer hell in this war . too many innocent people have been killed , including thousand of child . it ’ s time to begin this new stage . the hostage come home , for israel to be secure , for the suffering to stop . it ’ s time for this war to end , and for the day after to begin . thank you very much . byzolan kanno-youngsanddavid e . sanger zolan kanno-youngs reported from rehoboth beach , del . , where president biden will be spending the weekend . david e . sanger reported from washington . declaring hamas no longer capable of carrying out a major terrorist attack on israel , president biden said on friday that it wa time for a permanent cease-fire in gaza and endorsed a new plan he said israel had offered to win the release of hostage and end the fighting . “ it ’ s time for this war to end , for the day after to begin , ” mr . biden said , speaking from the state dining room at the white house . he also gave a stark description of hamas ’ s diminished capability after more than seven month of israeli attack , saying that “ at this point , hamas is no longer capable of carrying out another oct . 7 . ” “ this is truly a decisive moment , ” mr . biden said . “ israel ha made their proposal . hamas say it want a cease-fire . this deal is an opportunity to prove whether they really mean it . ” with that statement , mr . biden appeared to be revealing his true agenda : making public element of the proposal in an effort to pressure both hamas and israel to break out of a monthslong deadlock that ha resulted in the killing of thousand of palestinian . american official have describedhamas ’ s leader , yahya sinwar , a interested only in his own survival and that of his family and inner circle , a they presumably operate from tunnel deep under southern gaza . but official have also said prime minister benjamin netanyahu of israel ha little incentive to move to a real cease-fire , because of the widespread belief in israel that a soon a the surviving hostage are returned , and a last cease-fire begin , he will most likely lose his fragile hold on power . mr . biden ’ s remark came at a pivotal moment in his re-election campaign , a day after his rival , former president donald j . trump , wa convicted of 34 felony charge . at the same time , he ha been facing growing pressure at home over the bloodshed in gaza , which ha led to eruption on college campus and on the street of american city , and alienated many of his own supporter . we are
