alan rappeport reported from stresa , italy , where he is covering the group of 7 finance minister meeting . treasury secretary janet l . yellen warned israel on thursday againstcutting off tiesbetween palestinian and israeli bank , arguing that such a move would further destabilize the economy of the west bank when palestinian were already facing dire economic condition . m . yellen ’ s comment came in the wake of israel ’ s decision on wednesday to withhold tax revenue from the palestinian authority in retaliation for three european country ’ unilaterally agreeing to recognize a palestinian state . m . yellen and other top economic official from the group of 7 nation are expected to discus the matter and the humanitarian situation in gaza during their summit in stresa , italy , which begin on thursday . “ i ’ m particularly concerned by israel ’ s threat to take action that would lead to palestinian bank ’ being cut off from their israeli correspondent bank , ” m . yellen said during remark ahead of a news conference . m . yellen added that the banking channel were critical for processing transaction that allow $ 8 billion a year of import of food , fuel and electricity from israel and $ 2 billion of palestinian export . the war in gaza is one of several geopolitical crisis that are weighing on the global economy . the economic policymakers are also planning to discus russia ’ s war in ukraine and continue deliberation over how to use more than $ 300 billion of frozen russian central bank asset to provide ukraine with additional aid . official from the group of 7 will also be discussing way to tighten sanction on russia and how to prevent china from providing the country with military support . m . yellen said on thursday that the plight of the palestinian would be a topic of discussion with her counterpart and that a move to cut palestinian off from the international financial system could fuel a “ humanitarian crisis . ” we are having Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement the deadly strike on a united nation school-turned-shelter is a bitter reminder , gazans say , that each place they flee eventually get caught up in the bloodshed . byerika solomonandabu bakr bashir a mother begs her dead child to take her hand . a young man , wrapped in bandage , lie weeping next to the corpse of another man . a little boy , his face coated in dust and blood , stare vacantly from a hospital floor a people shout frantically around him . the scene at the doorstep of the last functioning hospital in central gaza , posted on social medium by a palestinian videographer after an israeli strike hit a united nation school complex , have yet again highlighted the awful dilemma that palestinian civilian keep facing through eight month of war : the place where they seek refuge often end up being attacked . the video were posted to instagram on thursday after the strike . the new york time verified that they were shot at al aqsa martyr hospital in the central gaza city of deir al balah . in the early morning hour of thursday , israel launched a strike on a school complex housing thousand of displaced palestinian who had sought shelter there . dozen were killed . israel say it attack targeted and killed hamas operative using the school building a a base . palestinian medical worker say it killed civilian . of at least 40 dead body from the attack registered by gaza ’ s health ministry , 14 were child and nine were woman , the ministry said . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in your browser setting . thank you for your patience while we verify access . if you are in reader mode please exit andlog intoyour time account , orsubscribefor all of the time . thank you for your patience while we verify access . already a subscriber ? log in . want all of the time ? subscribe . advertisement

generated image showing a field of refugee tentsspelling out “ all eye on rafah . ” one version of the graphic ha been shared more than 38 million time on instagram . the phrase may have originated in comment made in february by rik peeperkorn , who head the world health organization ’ s office for gaza and the israeli-occupied west bank . mr . peeperkorn wa speaking at a news conference a the israeli military intensified it campaign in the southern gaza strip . “ all eye are on rafah , ” mr . peeperkornsaid at the time . the comment wa almost immediately repurposed by pro-palestinian and humanitarian group to draw attention to gaza and rafah , which wa one of the last remaining destination for displaced palestinian from other part of the territory . among them were save the child international , oxfam and , later , pro-palestinian lobbying group like jewish voice for peace . the saying wa also heard at pro-palestinianproteststhat swept across western university earlier this month . the deadlystrikein rafah on sunday wa quicklydenouncedby world leader . prime minister benjamin netanyahu of israel said the attack had killed two hamas official , and he called the civilian death a “ tragic accident . ” ali watkinsis a reporter on the metro desk , covering crime and law enforcement in new york . previously , she covered national security in washington for the time , buzzfeed and mcclatchy newspapers.more about ali watkins advertisement

Body Text: advertisement supported by the official , christine abizaid , recently warned that the hamas attack in israel , and the gaza conflict , had energized terrorist threat worldwide . byeric schmitt reporting from washington the director of the national counterterrorism center will step down next month , biden administration official said on wednesday . the director , christine s . abizaid , ha served three year a the country ’ s top counterterrorism official . in recent year , a resurgent china and russia , a well a the war in ukraine and in gaza , have replaced counterterrorism a the country ’ s main national security priority . but speaking to asecurity conferencein doha , qatar , last month , m . abizaid warned that the hamas attack against israel on oct . 7 , and the ensuing gaza conflict , had energized an increasingly diverse set of worldwide terrorist threat . the islamic state no longer control vast swath of territory in iraq and syria , but it fighter and group aligned with al qaeda are on the march in africa . the islamic state affiliate in afghanistan , isi khorasan , dramatically demonstrated it expanding reach earlier this year , conducting deadly attack iniranandrussia . in addition to supporting hamas in gaza , iran back extremist group in lebanon , syria , iraq and yemen . “ we are in an elevated global threat environment , ” m . abizaid said at the conference . m . abizaid , 45 , had previously served a a senior counterterrorism official at the white house and a a senior pentagon official for southwest asia policy before taking over the counterterrorism center in june 2021 . the counterterrorism center , created in the wake of the attack on sept . 11 , 2001 , integrates , analyzes and share counterterrorism information to address threat . “ christy abizaid is an extraordinary leader who is not only incredibly effective but principled , courageous and kind , ” avril d . haines , the director of national intelligence , said in a statement . m . abizaid started her government career a a counterterrorism intelligence analyst at the defense intelligence agency , specializing in afghanistan and pakistan , a well a the middle east , and including a tour a the agency ’ s senior representative in iraq . she is the daughter of john p . abizaid , a retired army general who formerly led the pentagon ’ s central command , overseeing military operation in the middle east and part of asia . “ christy ha played an indispensable role in driving the counterterrorism enterprise for the u.s . government even a other high-priority national security challenge draw resource and attention , ” said nicholas j . rasmussen , a former director of the counterterrorism center who is now at the homeland security department . brett m . holmgren , the assistant secretary of state for intelligence and research , will serve a the acting director of the counterterrorism center when m . abizaid departs in mid-july , administration official said . eric schmittis a national security correspondent for the time , focusing on u.s . military affair and counterterrorism issue overseas , topic he ha reported on for more than three decades.more about eric schmitt advertisement

the leader of the all-boys collegiate school in manhattan justfour year ago , announced on monday that he and the board had agreed he would leave his post a head of school . “ after four year filled report a “ a joke ” and a “ power play by jewish family . ” mr . lourie andjonathan youngwood , the president of the school ’ s board of trustee , did not immediately respond to request for comment . collegiate is among numerous private school across new york city that have experienced intense disagreement over how administrator and faculty member have addressed the israel-hamas war . resolved the challenge facing the israeli government . byisabel kershner reporting from jerusalem for month , israeli had heard only about hostage being killed or declared dead in gaza . the “ lucky ” family were those whose loved one ’ remains were retrieved by soldier , at great risk , and brought home to israel for burial . so the audacious rescue on saturday of four living hostage instantly raised morale in israel and offered at least a momentary victory for the country ’ s embattled prime minister , benjamin netanyahu . but by sunday , euphoria wa already giving way to a harsher reality . the heavy air and ground assault that accompanied the rescue killed score of palestinian , including civilian , according to gaza health official , puncturing israel ’ s claim that the operation wa a resounding success , at least internationally . and the operation failed to resolve any of the deep dilemma and challenge vexing the israeli government , according to analyst . eight month into it grinding war in gaza , israel still appears to be far from achieving it stated objective of dismantling hamas ’ s military and governing capability . and israeli fear that time is running out for many of the hostage in gaza . about a third of the 120 that remain have already been declared dead by israeli authority . at the same time , israel ’ s leadership is grappling with an escalation of hostility across the northern border with lebanon and battling increasing international isolation and opprobrium over the war in gaza , includingallegations of genocidethat are being heard by the Body Text: middle eastcrisis advertisement supported by iraqi want to help palestinian but say they are still recovering from their own war and fear playing host to a proxy fight between iran and the united state . byalissa j . rubin reporting from baghdad iraqi have known the bitter taste of war so intimately and frequently over the past 40 year that they say they can feel viscerally the suffering of palestinian in gaza . they remember the dreaded whistling of a shell before impact , the fear of a knock at the door bringing word of a loved one ’ s loss , the stench of blood drying on concrete . this wa daily life for many iraqi for year a an insurgent struggle against the american occupation and a civil war between sunni and shia muslim brought destruction and death to their neighborhood , shattered family and left behind countless widow and orphan . those memory initially prompted thousand of peopleto join demonstrationson the street of iraq ’ s city to show their solidarity with the palestinian cause . but a the war in gaza dragged on , those display of support faded . “ you want to help , ” said yasmine salih , a 25-year old dental student , referring to the plight of the palestinian in gaza , “ but you can ’ t because your own bucket of trouble is full . ” nowhere is that sense more vivid than in baghdad ’ s historic adhamiyah neighborhood , where most people follow the sunni branch of islam — a do most palestinian . a number here took up arm against the american military occupation of iraq that began in 2003 , and they view the israeli assault on gaza a a similar fight against an occupying force . many people in the neighborhood cheered when they heard the news of the hamas-led attack on israel on oct . 7 . but since then , the crowd have dwindled , partly because of a recognition that their effort could do little to help palestinian , resident say . we are having trouble retrieving the article content . please enable javascript in school building on thursday appeared to have been made in the united state , according to a weapon expert and video reviewed by the new york time . the school , located in nuseirat , in central gaza , identifiedthe part of the weapon seen in the footage a the nose of a gbu-39 . “ this distinct nose is unique to the gbu-39 munition series , and , due to it solid construction , it can survive the Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement transcript in the occupied west bank , palestinian live in the shadow of the ongoing war in gaza . for them , this ha meant increased raid and arrest , tightening security restriction , settler violence and economic turmoil . we spent time with two palestinian whose life and livelihood are being reshaped by the war and who worry that some of these change may be long lasting . 29-year-old taxi driver and tour guide laith al-muti now wait all day here at one of the israeli-controlled checkpoint into bethlehem . but these day , barely any visitor come through . thirteen mile away in the tel rumeida area of hebron , wijdan ziadeh ’ s life is also at a standstill . the site of an israeli settlement , palestinian in the area say their movement , limited before the war , ha felt even more restricted since oct . 7 . control over security in hebron is divided into two zone . h1 is managed by the palestinian authority and h2 , where ziadeh life , is managed by the israeli military . the israeli military told the time that security measure have increased in the west bank a part of a response to terrorist operative , including hamas , and that their force are in tel rumeida to help ensure the safety of all resident . but ziadeh life in fear of scene of settler aggression like this one captured by a nearby palestinian resident . ziadeh say since the war , her settler neighbor have become even more aggressive towards her and her two son . throughout the west bank , incident of settler violence against palestinian jumped in the aftermath of oct . 7 , according to the u.n . , who have recorded nearly 950 attack a of june 2024 . palestinian in the area say that the israeli military are there to protect the settler and that settler violence against palestinian largely go unpunished , a decades-long pattern detailed in a recent time investigation . back in bethlehem , laith also fear for the future . site he used to frequent with tourist , like the church of the nativity , now sit empty . al-muti and ziadeh say they don ’ t know what ’ s next for them or for others in the west bank . bysarah kerr a the war in gaza enters it eighth month , palestinian living under israeli occupation in the west bank continue to faceonerous restriction , economic difficulty and an increased military presence — change that some worry may become the new normal . throughout the west bank , daily life — restricted before oct . 7 — ha been further complicated by myriad factor . these include regular raid and arrest by israeli force , emboldened settler and regulation that have hampered the economy , such a the cancellation of permit to work in israel and an increase in internal checkpoint and roadblock , complicating movement throughout the territory . the israeli military said there had been a “ significant increase ” in terrorist attack in the west bank since the beginning of the war and told the new york time that arrest of suspected “ terrorist operative , ” a well a the strategic placement of security force , were necessary “ to improve the safety of all resident of the sector . ” we spent time with two palestinian in the west bank to learn how they have been affected by these change . in bethlehem , a city whose economy islargely dependent on tourism , few are arriving to visit site like the church of the nativity , the supposed birthplace of jesus . laith al-muti , 29 , a local tour guide and taxi driver , spends his day waiting at the main checkpoint from jerusalem into bethlehem , hoping to attract local fare . al-muti and other driver said they were making a fraction of what they earned before the war . “ i don ’ t know for how long people will have energy , ” said al-muti . “ i might be making 20 or 40 shekel , ( roughly $ 5 - $ 11 ) working in my taxi , but some people haven ’ t earned one shekel in seven month . ” thirteen mile away in the tel rumeida area of hebron , widjan ziadeh , 56 , a widow , and her son live in fear . hebron is divided into two zone : h1 , where security is controlled by the palestinian authority , and h2 , where security is controlled by the israeli military . tel rumeida , located in h2 , is surrounded by israeli-run checkpoint . since the war , palestinian in the area said they had been subject to increased restriction and difficulty . tel rumeida , the site of an israeli settlement , ha some who are violent and aggressive , according to palestinian in the area , and tension have run high for decade . ziadeh said her son faris , 20 , had nearly lost all vision in one eye following a settler attack in 2022 , but the family never filed a criminal complaint to the israeli authority because oflimited expectation of justice . for now , ziadeh is determined to stay and keep her house from being taken over by settler . “ we won ’ t leave . this is our land and we ’ ll stay here , ” she said . “ we ’ ll live and die in suffering . ” sarah kerris a time senior video journalist covering news and investigations.more about sarah kerr advertisement

Body Text: advertisement supported by the two president , in a brief appearance before reporter , declined to take question , in a departure from tradition . bymichael d . shearandpeter baker reporting from paris president biden and president emmanuel macron of france stressed on saturday how much they agreed with each other about world affair , including the war in ukraine , even a their country have expressed sharply different view of the fighting in gaza between israel and hamas . appearing briefly together in front of reporter after two day of d-day remembrance and hour before a lavish state dinner at the élysée palace in paris , the two president declined to take any question and papered over their stark difference about the middle east . instead , they both asserted the enduring strength of the american-french partnership on climate , the economy , european security and cultural tie . “ today , i proudly stand with france to support freedom and democracy around the world , ” mr . biden said , a the two men emerged from a closed-door meeting at the élysée palace . “ we see eye to eye on this war raging in ukraine , ” mr . macron noted , and he added that he hoped “ all member of the g7 will agree to a $ 50 billion solidarity fund for ukraine , ” referring to the group of 7 industrialized nation . the french president ’ s comment suggested that the two leader had reached common ground over a plan to leverage proceeds from frozen russian asset to provide an upfront loan of up to $ 50 billion to ukraine . american official had said heading into the meeting that france wa the main holdout for such a plan and that they were hoping to win support during the paris visit . on gaza , mr . macron noted his government ’ s support for an israeli cease-fire proposal that mr . biden ha strongly backed . but the french president also directly challenged israel to do more to deliver aid to palestinian suffering from the government ’ s bombardment . we are Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement supported by relief organization say cumbersome new strategy can not substitute for israel allowing more supply truck into the gaza strip , while an airdrop of aid reportedly went awry and killed five people . byhiba yazbek , aaron boxerman , monika pronczukandthomas fuller a day after president biden announced plan for maritime aid delivery to the gaza strip , european leader said friday they would deliver aid by ship a early a the weekend . but aid group and gaza official criticized shipment by air or sea a too cumbersome , urging that vastly more food and medicine be supplied by truck . the complication of delivering aid to the hungry resident of gaza were underlined on friday when the authority in gaza said at least five palestinian were killed and several others were wounded after they were struck by package of humanitarian aid that were dropped from an aircraft . the united nation ha warned that five month of war and an israeli blockade have left hundred of thousand of gazans on the brink of starvation , prompting a variety of proposal to speed the delivery of food and other vital need . israel insists on inspecting all supply going into gaza , and aid truck have been allowed in through just two border crossing — one from egypt and one from israel — in southern gaza . president biden on thursday night outlined a u.s . military plan to build a floating pier on gaza ’ s mediterranean coast to supply food , water , medicine and other necessity to civilian , saying the operation would “ enable a massive increase ” in the assistance entering the territory . the pentagon press secretary , maj . gen . pat ryder , said in a news conference on friday that the pier would help to deliver a many a two million meal a day . the gaza strip ha a population of about 2.3 million . but u.s . official said the project would take at least 30 to 60 day to complete , raising question about how famine in gaza will be staved off in question . from “ the new york time , ” i ’ m sabrina tavernise . and this is “ the daily . ” late last week , an effort to get food into northern gaza turned deadly , a thousand of desperate gazans descended on aid truck and israeli troop tasked with guarding those truck opened fire . but exactly how people died and who wa responsible remains contested . today , my colleague hiba yazbek on what we know about what happened and what it tell u about hunger in gaza . it ’ s tuesday , march 5 . so hiba , we are now in the fifth month of israel ’ s war against hamas in gaza . and for week , we ’ ve been hearing about negotiation over a cease fire and a hostage exchange . then , late last week , there wa a disaster surrounding an aid convoy that wa brought into gaza . you ’ ve been reporting on what happened . tell u about it . so last thursday , there wa a deadly disaster involving civilian , possibly the deadliest disaster since the war started nearly five month ago , in which 118 palestinian were killed and more than 760 were wounded in gaza city . but there are conflicting report on how they died and what exactly happened . the israeli military ha one account of what happened and the gaza health ministry and witness have another account . so my colleague and i started digging into the detail . we started calling people , piecing together a picture of what had actually happened there . and what did you find when you guy started really looking into this ? so first , let me just give you the context of what happened . this happened in northern gaza , the place that ha been at war the longest . that ’ s where israeli ground force began their invasion of the gaza strip . many people have left the north . but we do know that some 300,000 people are still there . the people who have remained there are really living through very desperate condition . very little aid ha come in to the north of gaza since the war started and especially in recent week . food is barely available for the people who ’ ve remained there . the un ha been warning of a famine that is looming over the territory . hiba , why is there so little aid getting into northern gaza in particular ? well , first of all , there ’ s less aid getting into the gaza strip in general , not just the north . there ’ s multiple reason a to why that is . but one of the main reason is that israel itself ha been very slow to approve permit and often denies permit for aid truck and aid convoy to come in , specifically to the north . because israel say that they don ’ t want the aid to end up in the hand of hamas , that they don ’ t want them to get a hold of the package . got it . when israel doe approve the permit and the aid truck start their journey , there ’ s multiple hurdle that they have to go through in order to actually deliver it to the people . some of these hurdle include the widespread destruction in gaza . there ’ s vast damage across the gaza strip . road have been destroyed , there ’ s rubble everywhere , and it ’ s very difficult for the truck to actually move through that rubble and through those road . then these aid convoy have to go through multiple israeli checkpoint on the way . there ’ s often significant delay at these checkpoint by israeli soldier who are inspecting the aid . this make it hard for the truck to make it from where they enter in the south all the way to the north in the specific safety window that they ’ re given . sometimes they make it halfway through and they turn around because they got delayed so much that they can ’ t keep going . hm . but there ’ s a particular problem with the north , where fighting ha been going on the longest . the civil order is now breaking down , essentially . we know that frequent israeli strike on palestinian policeman meant that there ’ s really no one to run security for official group and for aid convoy , leaving them vulnerable to attack by local gang who are trying to steal the aid and sell it or profit off of it , and also , hungry and desperate civilian who are trying to grab the aid and take a much a they can , which mean that they end up stealing some of it , looting some of it , while it ’ s still on the way . right . so it ’ s lawlessness and effectively social order breakdown . i mean , this is kind of the downstream effect of extended war in a particular place . there ’ s a power vacuum . that situation can be very difficult for an organization like the united nation to be able to operate safely . right . the few aid truck that do come in have had to either suspend their aid delivery into the north or have not been able to deliver aid there . the last time unrwa , the un agency in charge of palestinian refugee , tried to bring truck to the north wa nearly a month ago . but they said that one of their convoy came under fire . another major aid provider , the world food program , said that they haven ’ t delivered aid there in over three week . they cited all of the reason we talked about for this suspension . so while aid hasn ’ t been coming into the north , people have been growing more desperate and hungry and the situation there ha been getting worse , which ha been raising international alarm . there ’ s been increased call on israel to let aid go through to the north and to alleviate the suffering of the resident there . so israel partnered with these local palestinian businessmen in gaza , and they promised to secure the aid convoy that the businessmen would supply and that would make their way into the north . they successfully did this three time last week . so people started being very hopeful that more would come , and ahead of the fourth delivery , they started to gather at this distribution point right outside of gaza city in the north . that brings u to thursday ’ s incident . [ music playing ] so last thursday around 4:45 am , around 38 aid truck reached this distribution point . they start getting closer to the crowd of people who had camped there overnight waiting for this aid to come . when the people see the truck coming , they ’ re very desperate . they surround them . they get on top of them . then at some point , israeli soldier start firing shot . then it turned violent very fast . it ended with 118 palestinian dead and 760 injured . this is where the account diverge . ok . so let ’ s start with the israeli account . what do they say happened ? so the israeli military said that it wa trying to secure the convoy and it had tank nearby to make sure that the convoy reached the area . it did acknowledge that it troop had opened fire at the crowd , but they said that they opened fire when a violent crowd or a violent mob approached their troop and endangered their life . they said the shot that were fired weren ’ t really the reason why so many people died , but the reason that so many people died wa because , in the chaos of all of it , they trampled each other and many had died from suffocation or trampling , and also that the truck had run over some of the people who were trying to run away . oh , god . so the israeli don ’ t deny actually shooting , but they say it wa more about controlling the crowd , kind of a warning shot type thing , and that this wa not the way people actually died . they say the way people actually died wa suffocation or being crushed by the aid truck themselves . right . what did the gazan health authority say ? so the gazan health authority have actually been calling this the flour massacre , or the massacre of the hungry stomach . because what they ’ re saying is that israeli force fired at a crowd of hungry and desperate people who were waiting for aid . witness and palestinian who were there have said that although some people were trampled and possibly run over by the truck , that wa not the main reason for the high death toll . most of the people who were injured or killed were injured and killed by israeli fire . so the gazan health authority are essentially saying this wa a massacre by israel . right . do we know , hiba , what actually did happen ? what have you guy found in your reporting ? well , the israeli military released drone footage that it claimed showed a mass stampede in which gazans are trampled . but that video only added to the confusion of the sequence of event . the quality and the length of the clip made it more difficult to confirm these claim . right . it wa just grainy . there wa no sound . you saw people scramble and run , but you didn ’ t understand why . right . the drone footage wa heavily edited . it left out key moment . but it did show hundred of people circling around the truck and hoping to catch a bag of flour . then suddenly , we see people start to panic and run in multiple direction . then they released another clip in which we see two israeli tank that are positioned about a quarter mile down the road . then we see about a dozen body lying around them . we see people crawling and ducking for cover . [ crowd noise ] but we did have another video that wa released by al jazeera . [ gunfire ] and it showed a crowd near the aid convoy . and it also captured the sound of gunfire and showed multiple tracer round , which is a special type of ammunition that help troop fine tune their targeting when it ’ s dark . the tracer round originated from the direction of a nearby israeli military base . so although that did not conclude that the shot came from the direction of the israeli military , it did add another layer of evidence . so hiba , it sound like these video are suggestive but not conclusive . but what did the people you spoke to on the ground say , the eyewitness and survivor and doctor you spoke with . right . we spoke to witness and survivor a well a doctor at the hospital that have taken in the people who were wounded and killed . they said that most of the people had died or were wounded by gunshot . the doctor who run one of the four main hospital in the area that took in the casualty told me that out of the 13 people who were killed and the 170 people who were wounded that the hospital took in , all of the injury were of gunshot wound . he said that they didn ’ t see any injury that coincided with those of a stampede or people being run over by truck . that account echo the one that we ’ ve heard from witness and people who were there , who saw people get shot and fall to the ground next to them . but in the chaos of everything , people were not checking who ’ s dead and who ’ s wounded . they were just taking the flour , and they were running for their life . and although the account differ on both side , what we do know is that many hungry and desperate people died while trying to get food and secure aid in a place where famine is looming and starvation is rampant . that ’ s what i spent the last few week reporting on . i ’ m trying to understand how people in the north of gaza specifically are surviving with such little food . we ’ ll be right back . so hiba , i want to talk about what people are doing to survive in northern gaza . but before we get to that , what is the big picture on the state of hunger in gaza ? hunger ha reached unprecedented level in gaza and specifically in northern gaza . we ’ re starting to already see report of child dying from malnutrition and dehydration . this week , the health ministry said that 15 child have died from malnutrition and dehydration at just one of northern gaza ’ s hospital . wow , 15 child have actually died ? yes . we also have the un and aid organization saying that one in six child in northern gaza were acutely malnutritioned and that more than 90 percent of child under two are facing severe food poverty . the un humanitarian coordinator said that a quarter of all gazan resident are one step away from famine . how exactly are people surviving , hiba ? i mean , you ’ re talking to people in northern gaza . what are they saying ? i ’ ve been reporting on hunger for week . i ’ ve talked to people about what they ’ re doing in order to survive with such little food . [ non-english speech ] . [ non-english speech ] . i recently talked to one woman whose experience is very typical in northern gaza . her name is ghada krayem . she ’ s a 23-year-old woman from the north who stayed in the north and didn ’ t flee . tell me about ghada . [ non-english speech ] . ghada is one of 10 kid . she ha six sister and three brother . she ’ s actually gaza ’ s first female solar power engineer . she ’ s won many award internationally . she ’ s also the sole provider for her family . she ’ s used the money that she won from these grant and competition to help her family through this war . with that money , she actually stockpiled a bunch of food in the beginning of the war , expecting the situation to deteriorate . she bought flour and milk and canned food and everything they might need . they stockpiled it in their home . how is it that they ’ re still in northern gaza ? well , actually , they tried to stay in their home for a long a they possibly could , until the ground fighting really basically reached their doorstep . [ non-english speech ] . at one point , early on during israel ’ s ground invasion of the north — [ non-english speech ] . — israeli soldier came to their building and they forced them out . they asked everyone to leave the building , and they detained all of the men and the boy , who were later released . she wa forced to leave with nothing . they took nothing with them , like many other gazans . and they moved . they moved 12 time since . wow . one of those time wa to the south , where they got there and they realized that it actually wasn ’ t much safer . it wasn ’ t better for them . so they realized that they should probably just go back to the north and stay a close a possible to their home in case they ’ re able to go back later . but that never happened because israeli force took up their home a a military base and they were there for two week , she said . [ non-english speech ] . after they ’ d left , two week later , she went back to check on her home . it wa burned . there wa nothing left , including the food that she ’ d stockpiled . now she ’ s sheltering with 50 member of her extended family , including child , in a two bedroom apartment in the north . 50 people in a two bedroom apartment ? that is extraordinary . so what did they do for food early in the war ? well , she told me that in the beginning of the war , they still were able to find some thing to buy and eat , like rice and vegetable . but — [ non-english speech ] . she said that by the end of december , basically , when aid to the north became less frequent and thing that they were eating had started to run out , including flour , which became much less available and much more expensive . they didn ’ t know what to do . i mean , they had nothing to eat , so they started mixing water with starch to eat . they were having one meal a day . and the child were constantly hungry , so they had to find an alternative . that alternative wa animal food . [ non-english speech ] . so she told me that they started grinding up , really , any animal food that they could find . so rabbit food and bird food and hay and fodder , really anything that they could get their hand on . they would use that to make bread with . but the bread wa very dry , and it smelled bad , it tasted bad , and it made their stomach hurt . but she said that the one that wa the worst for her wa the bird food . [ non-english speech ] . she said the bird food tasted and smelled a if you were sitting with a bunch of chicken . the smell wa very bad and the taste wa even worse . [ non-english speech ] . but she told me that even though this stuff tasted and smelled bad , they really tried to make it a less awful a possible . she told me that one of her cousin sheltering with her loved to bake , and she made really tasty sweet before the war . so basically , she tried to make the most out of these ingredient . she wa making dessert using the corn mill and the rabbit food . she wa also making other savory dish that they liked and they ate frequently before the war . [ non-english speech ] . she used the animal feed to make maftoul , which is the palestinian version of couscous . so she wa making it with the ground up animal feed ? yes . but that wa still not enough . at that point , ghada and her family were only eating one meal a day and that wa not enough for them or the child in the family . [ non-english speech ] . [ non-english speech ] . she told me that her little sister , two-year-old elene , who is actually the youngest person sheltering with them , wa hungry all the time . she wa going to sleep cry and waking up cry . and she loved milk , but they ran out of milk more than two month ago . so what they ’ ve been doing is basically giving her expired juice . it wa actually not even juice , it ’ s a concentrated juice that they would mix with water . because it wa expired , it wa making her sick . but that wa the only thing that they could give her in place of milk . when they were able to , they would give her sugar cane that they would find in the market and lemon a a snack . sometimes when those weren ’ t even available , they would just give her gum to chew on and stop cry , to silence her hunger . [ non-english speech ] . so i asked her if they had been able to get any aid since the war started . she told me that her brother muhammad , who ’ s 30 year old , had been going to the distribution site and sleeping on the beach just waiting for aid . he would leave at 7:00 in the morning and come back at 3:00 am . he slept there for three day this week . so her brother had been sleeping on the beach in hope that there would be aid dropped off here . so what happened ? so after waiting for hour near the distribution site on thursday , he saw the eight truck coming . and along with the crowd , he ran towards them . suddenly , when the chaos erupted , he just started seeing people dropping to the ground . he ’ s actually deaf and mute . so he didn ’ t know what wa happening . he just saw people get shot and fall to the ground in front of him . she told me that he saw someone get shot in the head right next to him . god . in the middle of all the chaos and the bloodshed , he wa actually able to grab a bag of flour . he just took it and started running really fast . he wa just trying to get away and hold on to that bag of flour that he wa able to get . while leaving the site , he saw this little kid who wa also able to grab a bag of flour . but she said that he told her that the kid wa stopped by local gang member who had attacked him and grabbed the bag of flour from him . they stole it from him . ghada ’ s brother just kept running until he got home , finally . he came home after three day of sleeping in the sand with a bag of flour . god , a terrifying night . mhm . but that wa the first time they ’ ve had flour in month , since december , basically . so obviously , they wanted to make bread . but that bag wa a 25 kilogram bag of flour . again , they were 50 people sheltering in one apartment . so they had to make it last them a long a possible so it could feed all the member of the family . so actually what they ’ re doing now is they ’ re mixing the flour with animal feed still . they ’ re doing one cup of flour with three cup of animal feed to stretch it out for a long a possible . they ’ re making bread with it . wow . she said that it wa better , but still not normal bread . it wa not what they were craving . [ non-english speech ] . they ’ ve been through so much since the war started . they ’ ve seen people killed . they ’ ve seen dead body . they ’ ve been displaced 12 time . they ’ ve lost friend and family member . but she said that now with the hunger and the starvation in the north , it ’ s really the worst thing they ’ ve gone through since the beginning of the war . she said that she ’ s seeing people , kid who are rummaging through trash , trying to find anything to eat . so she said that people were still going back to that same distribution site . she even said that more people were going back on the beach and waiting and camping out and sleeping there , hoping for more aid to come . she also said that her brother , muhammad , wa also going back every day since thursday , hoping to get another bag of flour . because he wa so hungry that he wanted to eat anything , and risking his life for a bag of flour wa worth it . despite the fact that so many people had died on thursday trying to get flour , the fact that some people did come home with a bag of flour , that wa enough for them and others to go back there in hope that more wa going to come . [ non-english speech ] . [ non-english speech ] . [ non-english speech ] . hiba , thank you . thank you , sabrina . over the weekend , the biden administration airdropped food into gaza for the first time . vice president kamala harris called for a cease fire , a position she pressed with a member of israel ’ s war cabinet , benny gantz , at the white house on monday . meanwhile , 15 truck were dispatched to northern gaza on monday . but at least five were looted along the way , and it wa unclear how many reached their intended destination . we ’ ll be right back . [ music playing ] here ’ s what else you should know today . on monday , the supreme court ruled that state may not bar former president donald trump from running for another term , rejecting a challenge to trump ’ s eligibility that had threatened to upend the presidential race . the case arose from a challenge brought by colorado voter who cited section iii of the 14th amendment , a provision adopted after the civil war to forbid those who had taken an oath to support the constitution from holding office if they engaged in insurrection . the justice agreed that individual state may not bar candidate from the presidency under that constitutional provision . it wa a unanimous decision that wa largely expected . and a united nation report released on monday found , quote , “ reasonable ground to believe that sexual violence , including rape wa committed in at least three location in israel during the october 7 attack , the nova music festival site , road 232 , and kibbutz re ’ im . ” the expert also said they had found circumstantial evidence that could indicate sexual violence had occurred with a number of victim , mostly woman , who were found fully or partially naked , bound , and shot . in addition , the un group said it had found clear and convincing information , based on firsthand account from released hostage , that sexual violence , including rape , wa inflicted against some woman during their time in captivity in gaza . the report said that the un team had also heard account of sexual violence against palestinian that implicated israeli security force and settler . today ’ s episode wa produced by sydney harper , rachelle bonja , and lynsea garrison . it wa edited by liz o . baylen and lisa chow . contains original music by dan powell , marion lozano , and elisheba ittoop and wa engineered by alyssa moxley . our theme music is by jim brunberg and ben landsverk of wonderly . that ’ s it for “ the ” daily . i ’ m sabrina tavernise . what have you guy found in your reporting ? well , the israeli military released drone footage that it claimed showed a mass stampede in which gazans are trampled . but that video only added to the confusion of the sequence of event . the quality and the length of the clip made it more difficult to confirm these claim . right . it wa just grainy . there wa no sound . you saw people scramble and run , but you didn ’ t understand why . right . the drone footage wa heavily edited . it left out key moment . but it did show hundred of people circling around the truck and hoping to catch a bag of flour . then suddenly , we see people start to panic and run in multiple direction . then they released another clip in which we see two israeli tank that are positioned about a quarter mile down the road . then we see about a dozen body lying around them . we see people crawling and ducking for cover . [ gunfire ] and it showed a crowd near the aid convoy . and it also captured the sound of gunfire and showed multiple tracer round , which is a special type of ammunition that help troop fine tune their targeting when it ’ s d

after it editor published anarticlethat argues palestinian are living under a “ brutally sophisticated structure of oppression ” by israel that amount to a crime against humanity . a of tuesday evening , visitor to thewebsiteof the 123-year-old journal saw only a blank page with the message “ website is under maintenance . ” the decision to suspend access to the website is the latest example of how american university have sought to regulate expression that is highly critical of israel amid concern that it veers into antisemitism . that , in turn , ha spurred complaint about censorship hundred of thousand of palestinian face a growing threat of famine after nearly five month of fighting and blockade . fifteen truck were dispatched overnight to northern gaza a part of a relief effort involving palestinian businessmen , according to cogat , the israeli military body that regulates aid to the palestinian . but at least five of those were looted along the way , according to an israeli official who wa not authorized to comment publicly , and so spoke on condition of anonymity . it wa unclear exactly how many of the truck reached their intended destination , gaza city ’ s zeitoun neighborhood . izzat aqel , a palestinian businessman involved in the operation , said he aimed to send an additional 30 truck with food relief to northern gaza on monday night . aid official have warned that palestinian in gaza could be on the brink of famine unless relief is substantially stepped up , with over 500,000 people already facing a dire lack of food . one in six child under the age of 2 in gaza is acutely malnourished , according to the united nation . tedros adhanom ghebreyesus , the director general of the world health organization , said visit to hospital in the north by agency official — the first since early october — found severe level of malnutrition and “ child dying of starvation . ” the dire condition have prompted crowd of desperate people to swarm aid truck and contributed to a bloody scene last week , when israeli troop opened fire on palestinian who had gathered en masse around a convoy of truck that had entered northern gaza . over 100 palestinian were killed , many by gunfire , according to palestinian health official . the israeli military said the troop had fired on member of the crowd who approached them in a threatening manner and attributed most of the death to a stampede around the convoy . in the wake of the bloodshed at the convoy , israel ha faced even greater international pressure to facilitate more aid for gazans , against israel that have undermined it international standing . the ruling came just day after prosecutor at the international criminal court , another international tribunal , called for thearrest of israel ’ s prime ministerand defense minister , a move that wa supported by some longstanding partner of israel , including france . the order came the same week thatthree european countriestook the suspend trade with israeland by belize , bolivia andcolombiato break diplomatic tie with israel . “ this is not north korea or belarus or myanmar level of isolation — but it is isolation , ” said alon pinkas , israel ’ s former consul general in new york . “ it creates a tremendous sense of pressure . ” the latest move by the international court of justice may not have immediate practical effect : under the term of the order , israel ha a month to show how it ha complied with it instruction . even if israel ignores the order , the i.c.j . ha no mean of enforcing it . in theory , the united specia when the irish government on wednesday announced formal recognition of an independent palestinian state , it drew on it own struggle for statehood and the violence that surrounded it . “ from our own history we know what it mean : recognition is an act of powerful political and symbolic value , ” simon harris , the taoiseach , or prime minister of ireland , said at a news briefing . mr . harris wa nodding to the republic of ireland ’ s quest for self-rule in the early part of the 20th century after hundred of year of british rule . he detailed how , on jan . 21 , 1919 , ireland asked the world to recognize it right to independence . “ our message to the free nation of the world wa a plea for international recognition of our independence , emphasizing our distinct national identity , our historical struggle and our right to self-determination and justice , ” he said . “ today we use the same language to support the recognition of palestine a a state . ” ireland condemned hamas after the group led the oct . 7 attack on israel that official there say killed some 1,200 people . and since the start of the conflict in gaza , it ha sharply rebuked israel for it assault that gazan authority say ha left more than 35,000 people dead . mr . harris emphasized that ireland ’ s announcement , which came on the same day a similar move byspain and norway , did not diminish his country ’ s relationship with israel . instead , he said , it wa an acknowledgment that israel and a state of palestine had an equal right to exist . we are having trouble retrieving the article content .
