Body Text: for more audio journalism and storytelling , download new york time audio , a new io app available for news subscriber . transcript this transcript wa created using speech recognition software . while it ha been reviewed by human transcriber , it may contain error . please review the episode audio before quoting from this transcript and email transcript @ nytimes.com with any question . from “ the new york time , ” i ’ m sabrina tavernise , and this is “ the daily . ” [ music playing ] earlier this week , the top prosecutor of the international criminal court requested arrest warrant for israel ’ s prime minister and it defense minister . the move shocked israeli and set up a possible showdown between the world ’ s top criminal court and israel , together with it biggest ally , the united state . today , my colleague , jerusalem bureau chief patrick kingsley , explains . [ music playing ] it ’ s thursday , may 23rd . [ music playing ] so , patrick , earlier this week , there wa a pretty surprising announcement by the international criminal court in the hague . it had to do with israel and hamas . tell u what happened . well , on monday morning , we were all taken by surprise by an announcement from the chief prosecutor at the icc , the international criminal court , the top criminal court in the world . it try individual accused of war crime . and the chief prosecutor announced that he wa requesting arrest warrant for five individual involved in the war between israel and hamas for crime against humanity . three of them were from hamas — yahya sinwar , the head of hamas within gaza , the hamas military commander , and the political leader of hamas , who ’ s based in qatar . but maybe the biggest news in this announcement wa that the chief prosecutor wa seeking the arrest of two of israel ’ s top leader — benjamin netanyahu , the prime minister , and yoav gallant , the defense minister . and this wa a massive bombshell . these two men are leader from a major u ally . they ’ re in regular contact with the u government , and they were being implicitly equated with the three top leader of an organization , hamas , that many consider a terrorist organization . and this equation sent shockwaves through israeli society and , indeed , around the world . so this is absolutely remarkable , patrick . i mean , i , for one , wa quite surprised by seeing this . i want to dig into it with you . so who is this prosecutor behind these request for these warrant ? and how did he reach this decision to go for them in the first place ? so the prosecutor ’ s name is karim khan , and he is a british lawyer , a british barrister . he is 54 . he ’ s led a very impressive career . he ha spent year working on human right case , both defending people and also prosecuting in such case . he wa involved in tribunal related to the war surrounding the breakup of the former yugoslavia , rwanda . he investigated islamic state crime in iraq . and in 2021 , he is appointed the top prosecutor at the icc . and what are his responsibility a top prosecutor ? well , it ’ s his job to travel the world and investigate allegation of human right abuse , war crime , crime against humanity , and in the process , play a key role in deciding who get prosecuted at the international criminal court . the icc and the icc prosecutor investigates and try people who would not be pursued by the judicial system within their country of origin . it step in when it seems like the domestic authority in any given country are not doing their job . and last year , he famously went after president putin in russia in connection with the war in ukraine . so at what point did this prosecutor , karim khan , turn his attention to israel and gaza ? well , he actually inherits an investigation from his predecessor that ’ s looking at israel ’ s conduct and also that of hamas during a previous war in 2014 between the two side . but then that get superseded on october 7th by the horror that we saw that day committed by hamas and then by the scale and damage caused by israel ’ s bombing campaign in it counterattack . and we begin to see not only revulsion and horror at what hamas had done in early october , but also growing criticism and condemnation of what israel and it air force did in it response . you ’ ll remember that earlier this year , the international court of justice , a separate court also in the hague , began to address claim that israel wa and is committing a genocide in gaza , a claim that israel strongly denies . right . that wa the case that south africa brought . we did an episode about that . yes , exactly . so a the world ’ s attention focus on this new conflict , so doe karim khan ’ s . also today , the international criminal court ’ s chief prosecutor , karim khan , qc , ha wrapped up a visit to israel and the occupied west bank . khan ha visited the region to investigate if war crime were committed on october 7th . we start to see him arrive in israel visiting some of the site that hamas attacked last year , talking to survivor , talking to leader , reviewing security camera footage , and so on . i have just come from the border of the rafah crossing , and we could see gaza , at least we could see crane that were on the territory of gaza . and he also visited the rafah crossing between egypt and gaza , talk to palestinian . at the ministry of justice in ramallah , the chief prosecutor of the world ’ s highest court . he go to the israeli occupied west bank , to ramallah , where the palestinian authority is based , building up evidence that led to this announcement on monday . [ music playing ] today , i ’ m filing application for warrant of arrest before pre-trial chamber i of the international criminal court . and he make this very dramatic announcement in a video . my office ha diligently collected evidence and interviewed survivor and eyewitness at the scene of at least six major attack location . flanked on each side by two of his deputy . i have reasonable ground to believe that three senior leader of hamas , yahya sinwar , mohammed deif and ismail haniyeh , bear criminal responsibility for the following international crime . and the accusation that he make against the three hamas leader focus on the violent action that hamas took on october 7th . extermination a a crime against humanity . murder a a crime against humanity . and he walked through a long list of charge stemming from the extraordinary violence during that attack . the taking of hostage a a war crime . rape and other act of sexual violence during captivity . and he say there are reasonable ground to believe that hostage taken from israel have been subject to sexual violence , including rape , while being held in captivity . and he cite assessment of medical record , video , and documentary evidence , a well a interview with victim and survivor . and i repeat and underline my call for the immediate release of all hostage taken from israel and for their immediate safe return to their family . so this prosecutor see the atrocity on october 7th and then what followed with hamas taking the hostage , abusing them , a crime against humanity . that ’ s what it amounted to in his view ? exactly . and what about the charge against the israeli ? these are slightly different . israeli prime minister benjamin netanyahu and minister of defense yoav gallant bear criminal responsibility for the following international crime . obviously , a lot of the outcry and horror at the war in gaza ha centered around israel ’ s airstrikes that have killed ten of thousand of gazans . but karim khan focus not on the military action of benjamin netanyahu and yoav gallant , his defense minister , but on the accusation of — starvation of civilian a a method of warfare . — starvation . the idea that israel ha allegedly sought to restrict and block aid delivery , food supply to gaza with the intent to starve the civilian population there . these individual , through a common plan , have systematically deprived the civilian population of gaza of object indispensable to human survival . and that ’ s primarily based on the fact that for the first two week of the war , until october 21st or so , israel blocked all aid entry to gaza after yoav gallant , the defense minister , one of these two israeli whose arrest mr . khan seek , said that he wa imposing a total siege on gaza — no food , no fuel , no electricity . and while that total siege wa eased towards the end of october , khan also note that there have been continuing restriction on essential supply , like food and medicine , ever since . that conduct took place alongside attack that killed civilian , the obstruction of aid delivery by humanitarian organization , and attack on aid worker that forced many of those same humanitarian organization to either cease operation or limit their life-saving effort in gaza . the implication is that the famine that he say is present in some area of gaza and imminent in other area is in part the responsibility of netanyahu and gallant . that starvation ha caused and continues to cause death , malnutrition , dehydration , and profound suffering among the population . my office charge netanyahu and gallant a co-perpetrators and a superior in the commission of these alleged crime . why is the focus of these charge starvation ? i mean , given that the airstrikes , a you say , were in many way really the focus of this war and certainly the focus of the world ’ s attention on this war , the civilian death from the military operation . why starvation ? karim khan doe not explain why he focus on starvation rather than israel ’ s military tactic , which he mention only in passing . but legal expert have said that it ’ s easier to prove that starvation wa used a a method of warfare than it is to prove that there have been any specific crime involved in any specific airstrikes . and that ’ s because under the rule of war and international law , it ’ s not necessarily illegal in and of itself to kill civilian during wartime . if a military assesses , with the help of military lawyer , that the likely civilian death toll caused by that strike is proportional to the value of the military target , then that , in many case , will be in accordance with the rule of war . if a military can prove that sense of proportionality , then it ’ s actually quite hard to prove that there wa any crime committed in the process . so in other word , military action are often weighed quite carefully . in the case of , say , a modern military like israel ’ s or the united state , there are lawyer that look at these thing . it ’ s not necessarily so easy to prove that something wa disproportionate and should be considered a crime . exactly . whereas with the crime of starvation , legal expert say that it ’ s potentially easier to prove that there wa some wrongdoing there because yoav gallant , the israeli defense minister , went on record in a public statement , and he announced that there would be a total siege on the territory of gaza . and that wa followed by an action , the action of closing off gaza ’ s border for the next two week , and no aid wa allowed in . during that time , there were restriction on electricity , water , fuel , a well a food . and that ’ s why legal expert think that karim khan ha gone after israel with the crime of starvation rather than focusing on their military operation . but i suppose just thinking about our coverage , patrick , and the conversation you and i have had , famine and starvation and a civilian population in extreme distress trapped in a small piece of territory is also not a small thing , right ? that is also something that make sense that the court would be considering . absolutely , it ’ s a huge thing . people don ’ t have to be hit by an airstrike to be living through an absolutely catastrophic situation . so these charge really seem to spell bad news for israel and for these two israeli leader , netanyahu and gallant . and it ’ s remarkable because these are men who , a you say , are some of america ’ s closest ally . i mean , they ’ re , you know , at the pentagon . they ’ re having meeting with president biden . and now , the chief prosecutor of the icc is saying that they are war criminal . yes , it is a very dramatic moment in the view of some people , a turning point , and certainly , we can say that it is one of the harshest rebuke of israel ’ s wartime conduct since october 7th . [ music playing ] but within israel , there ’ s been a very different reaction . and it ’ s not all bad news for benjamin netanyahu . [ music playing ] we ’ ll be right back . [ music playing ] so , patrick , what do israeli make of this announcement ? within israel , the reaction ha been very different . whether it ’ s netanyahu ’ s ally or his critic , there ha been almost uniform outrage that the prosecutor for the icc would make these accusation . and it mean that at a time of rising domestic criticism of prime minister netanyahu across the political spectrum , with only a very few exception , everyone ha rallied behind netanyahu and gallant . despite the fact that netanyahu is increasingly unpopular and even within his own government , there have been growing criticism of his wartime strategy . for example , just two day before the prosecutor ’ s announcement , one of the senior member of his own wartime cabinet , benny gantz , issued netanyahu with an ultimatum , warning him that he would quit the government if he did not spell out a plan for a post-war gaza . then , suddenly , the announcement come from karim khan that netanyahu and gallant are under investigation . and gantz is one of the first to come out with a condemnation of karim khan and a defense of the israeli government . that is the clearest example of how even critic of netanyahu have fallen in line , circled the wagon , and presented a united front . this is really interesting . so this action by the prosecutor ha kind of had the effect of actually closing division that were starting to appear in israeli society , effectively bringing netanyahu ’ s critic kind of back into his camp , or at least making it harder to criticize him . exactly . and israeli , in general , feel that israel ha always been targeted unfairly , held to a higher standard than many other country , and that this is , once again , another example of that , another example of israel being accused of thing that other country do but get away with . and there have been broadly three criticism from the israeli of the icc prosecutor . first , the israeli claim is that the icc prosecutor is making a horrible false equivalence between hamas , a terrorist organization , and israel , a democratic state . hamas raided israel and launched the bloodiest attack on jew in a single day since the holocaust . israel , in the eye of israeli , is fighting a righteous response to protect their citizen and to win back the liberty of the hostage that were captured on october 7th . [ music playing ] this guy is out to demonize israel . he ’ s doing a hit job . and netanyahu himself articulated some of the clearest version of this argument when he went on american television . he ’ s creating false symmetry , false fact , and he ’ s doing a grave injustice to the international court . and he called khan ’ s decision absurd , an effort to demonize israel and to hold it to far higher standard than any other country . he said it would have been a if after 9/11 — that ’ s like saying after 9/11 , well , i ’ m issuing arrest warrant for george bush , but also for bin laden . — arrest warrant had been issued for both osama bin laden and george bush . or after , in world war ii , well , i ’ m issuing arrest warrant for fdr , but also for hitler . it ’ s a hit job . it ’ s not serious . he ’ s out to defame israel , and he ’ s also pouring gasoline — [ music playing ] the second criticism from israeli ha been about process . the icc wa created about two decade ago by a treaty . more than 120 country have signed that treaty , but israel ha not . and israel contends that the prosecutor doesn ’ t have the authority , therefore , to go after israeli political leader . israeli also say that khan didn ’ t spend enough time assessing whether israel wa itself investigating these allegation within it own judicial system . remember that the icc is a court of last resort . it ’ s only supposed to intervene when a domestic judicial system is genuinely not making any effort to investigate the alleged crime . and israeli are saying that khan didn ’ t spend enough time investigating gallant and netanyahu . the icc prosecutor have spent 10 year investigating alleged crime committed during a previous war between israel and hamas , but this decision ha been issued within just a few month . and israeli are saying that khan jumped the gun in that sense . so the israeli are saying , look , we ’ re trying to get to it , but you just didn ’ t give u enough time . exactly . and they ’ ve even said that khan ’ s team wa supposed to be coming this very week to continue that conversation and assess whether israel wa genuinely looking into these allegation by itself . and that they misled israel by pretending that they would be making that assessment when , in fact , all along they were planning to request arrest warrant . interesting . so for israeli official , they ’ re seeing it a a kind of activist thing , a opposed to a neutral judicial decision . that ’ s their claim , at least . the prosecutor ’ s office say that they have tried to sincerely engage with israel on this issue , but that it ’ s become clear to them that israel doe not seriously investigate this kind of crime . so you said , there are three element to this . what ’ s the last ? the third and last element is on the content of the claim itself . israel flatly denies that it is responsible for the humanitarian crisis in gaza . it even denies that there is a famine or that the situation is on the point of a famine . it point out all the way in which it ha worked to get much more aid into gaza since october , including opening more crossing , allowing the u to create a pier on the shoreline of gaza . it ’ s allowed some country to airdrop aid . and certainly , the amount of aid that ha gone in recent month ha dwarfed the amount that wa going in october and november . and while it accepts that it soldier have obstructed and , at time , even killed aid worker , it say that that obscures the fact that it coordinate every day in detail with aid group to facilitate thousand of aid mission every month . isn ’ t israel ’ s argument that these shipment could also include thing that could be very useful for hamas , the group that just killed 1,200 of it citizen ? exactly . no one ’ s disputing , least of all israel , that israeli official are examining all the aid going into gaza . the dispute is about whether that ’ s necessary . israel say it is . it say that if it didn ’ t check , then some of these aid convoy might be smuggling in weapon or material that could be used to fight israel , to kill israeli civilian . and that , therefore , israel ha no choice but to examine some of these good going in . again , the counterargument is that israel ’ s check are far more stringent than they need to be and end up preventing the entry of everyday item that pose no military threat . ok , so that ’ s the israeli perspective . how doe the united state see the prosecutor ’ s request here ? i mean , the u , obviously , israel ’ s biggest ally . well , the american president , president biden , condemned it in no uncertain term . he said the prosecutor ’ s decision wa outrageous . and he condemned him for drawing an implicit equivalence between hamas and the leader of the state of israel . and why did biden come out so strongly against the prosecutor ? we know that humanitarian aid ha been a major concern for this administration . so why would biden be so opposed to something that really is calling out israel for this aid ? first of all , because israel is a major ally of the united state , and the united state want to show support for it ally . second of all , they fear that this kind of criticism , this kind of intervention , will actually make israel less , rather than more , likely to bring the war to a halt , because the feeling is that it will make israel more defensive and in turn batten down the hatch . the third reason is that the united state , historically , ha never been a particular fan of the international criminal court . we mentioned earlier that israel did not sign the treaty that created the icc . well , the united state did not do that either . and that ’ s in part because american leader fear that having an international global court undermines american sovereignty . they think it ’ s the role of the american judicial system to investigate american citizen . and there is a fear that with the united state so active militarily in many part of the world , that membership of the court , involvement in the court could pave the way for american soldier being tried for acting on behalf of the united state . and that could somehow dent american foreign policy goal across the world . ok , so the united state doesn ’ t really like this court , you know , ha troop in a lot of place , doesn ’ t want a court swooping in and prosecuting them when something go wrong . but i guess the question then , in my mind , patrick , is doe what this prosecutor is doing matter ? i mean , america is not a signatory . israel is not a signatory . so why is this important ? well , for the time being , it meaning is more symbolic than anything else . first , karim khan ha not issued an arrest warrant . he ha requested an arrest warrant for these five people . and three judge will now spend week and possibly month deciding whether to uphold those request . that process can be less than a month . in the case of vladimir putin , it wa just shy of a month . president bashir of sudan wa issued with a warrant . that process took roughly a year . when and if they do do that , however , there will be practical effect . if an arrest warrant is issued , it mean that any country that ’ s a member of the international criminal court , in theory , should arrest any of these individual if they enter their territory . that includes more than 120 country all over the world , much of europe , latin america , africa , and so on . yes , it ’ s true that the united state and israel are not signatory , and neither are turkey or qatar , two of the country where hamas official spend much of their time when they ’ re outside gaza . so there will still be place for official on either side of these accusation to travel to . but there are lot of other country , like france , italy , both place where benjamin netanyahu traveled in the past year , where , in theory , they will not be able to set foot . so the negotiation over the war can still continue , but if netanyahu travel to france or to italy , he could be arrested , which is pretty wild . yes , at least that ’ s the theory . the national authority in any given country still have to make a choice about whether they want to follow through with it . but would those country perhaps not arrest him out of deference to the united state ? i think the expectation is that if we got into this scenario , then someone like netanyahu simply just wouldn ’ t travel to such a country . but the truth is , we just don ’ t really know . we are entering unchartered water . so this is really isolating netanyahu in the world . should it go forward ? yes , isolating netanyahu and to some extent israel itself . and it ha not just practical implication for the physical movement of netanyahu and his defense minister , gallant , but it also compound israel ’ s relationship with foreign ally . it complicates israel ’ s ability to arm itself . more country may grow more unwilling to sell israel arm , or at least they ’ ll face growing pressure because of this decision not to do so . and it also could force the country to become ever more reliant on the united state a it becomes more of a pariah over it action in gaza . which , of course , put the united state in an even trickier position with an ally who ’ s been pretty hard to be friend with of late . right . and in truth , while the practical consequence of this move are still unknown , they do , in general , compound the sense that israel is facing more and more diplomatic consequence for it action . more than a decade ago , a former israeli prime minister warned that israel would face what he called a diplomatic tsunami if it conflict with the palestinian went unresolved . [ music playing ] and it ’ s possible that year later we ’ re starting to finally see what he meant . israel doe still have it supporter , many of them , but we ’ re also now seeing during this war a level of criticism that go above and beyond the kind that we ’ ve grown used to seeing directed at israel over the year . [ music playing ] in addition to the warrant request we ’ ve seen this week , we ’ ve obviously had an extraordinary wave of protest on american campus and elsewhere in the world . and earlier this year , we had a watershed moment when the international court of justice began hearing accusation of genocide against israel . and this week , several european country recognized palestine a a state . wow . so if the tsunami hasn ’ t yet arrived , we can at least say that the wave are getting stronger . [ music playing ] patrick , thank you . thank you . [ music playing ] on wednesday , the leader of spain , norway , and ireland announced that they would recognize an independent palestinian state . the move wa largely symbolic , but raised the concern that if neighboring country followed their lead , europe could become a counterweight to the american position that statehood for palestinian should come only from a negotiated settlement with israel . [ music playing ] we ’ ll be right back . [ music playing ] here ’ s what else you should know today . nikki haley , the former united nation ambassador who dropped her republican presidential bid in march , said on wednesday that she would vote for donald trump but stopped short of officially endorsing him . haley wa trump ’ s longest standing rival in the 2024 primary contest and had carved out an important lane for herself a the voice for voter looking for an alternative to the former president . her decision on whether to endorse him could play a pivotal role in the race . haley ha built a formidable network of high-dollar donor and a solid base of college-educated voter that trump need to win . and the city of uvalde , texas , ha reached a settlement with most of the family of child who were shot by a gunman at robb elementary school in 2022 . to avert a lawsuit , the city promised to overhaul the city ’ s police force , create a permanent memorial to the victim , and pay $ 2 million . [ music playing ] today ’ s episode wa produced by will reid and diana nguyen with help from shannon lin . it wa edited by liz o . baylen with help from michael benoist , contains original music by elisheba ittoop , marion lozano , and pat mccusker , and wa engineered by alyssa moxley . our theme music is by jim brunberg and ben landsverk of wonderly . [ music playing ] that ’ s it for “ the daily . ” i ’ m sabrina tavernise . see you tomorrow . [ music playing ] transcript this transcript wa created using speech recognition software . while it ha been reviewed by human transcriber , it may contain error . please review the episode audio before quoting from this transcript and email transcript @ nytimes.com with any question . from “ the new york time , ” i ’ m sabrina tavernise , and this is “ the daily . ” [ music playing ] earlier this week , the top prosecutor of the international criminal court requested arrest warrant for israel ’ s prime minister and it defense minister . the move shocked israeli and set up a possible showdown between the world ’ s top criminal court and israel , together with it biggest ally , the united state . today , my colleague , jerusalem bureau chief patrick kingsley , explains . [ music playing ] it ’ s thursday , may 23rd . [ music playing ] so , patrick , earlier this week , there wa a pretty surprising announcement by the international criminal court in the hague . it had to do with israel and hamas . tell u what happened . well , on monday morning , we were all taken by surprise by an announcement from the chief prosecutor at the icc , the international criminal court , the top criminal court in the world . it try individual accused of war crime . and the chief prosecutor announced that he wa requesting arrest warrant for five individual involved in the war between israel and hamas for crime against humanity . three of them were from hamas — yahya sinwar , the head of hamas within gaza , the hamas military commander , and the political leader of hamas , who ’ s based in qatar . but maybe the biggest news in this announcement wa that the chief prosecutor wa seeking the arrest of two of israel ’ s top leader — benjamin netanyahu , the prime minister , and yoav gallant , the defense minister . and this wa a massive bombshell . these two men are leader from a major u ally . they ’ re in regular contact with the u government , and they were being implicitly equated with the three top leader of an organization , hamas , that many consider a terrorist organization . and this equation sent shockwaves through israeli society and , indeed , around the world . so this is absolutely remarkable , patrick . i mean , i , for one , wa quite surprised by seeing this . i want to dig into it with you . so who is this prosecutor behind these request for these warrant ? and how did he reach this decision to go for them in the first place ? so the prosecutor ’ s name is karim khan , and he is a british lawyer , a british barrister . he is 54 . he ’ s led a very impressive career . he ha spent year working on human right case , both defending people and also prosecuting in such case . he wa involved in tribunal related to the war surrounding the breakup of the former yugoslavia , rwanda . he investigated islamic state crime in iraq . and in 2021 , he is appointed the top prosecutor at the icc . and what are his responsibility a top prosecutor ? well , it ’ s his job to travel the world and investigate allegation of human right abuse , war crime , crime against humanity , and in the process , play a key role in deciding who get prosecuted at the international criminal court . the icc and the icc prosecutor investigates and try people who would not be pursued by the judicial system within their country of origin . it step in when it seems like the domestic authority in any given country are not doing their job . and last year , he famously went after president putin in russia in connection with the war in ukraine . so at what point did this prosecutor , karim khan , turn his attention to israel and gaza ? well , he actually inherits an investigation from his predecessor that ’ s looking at israel ’ s conduct and also that of hamas during a previous war in 2014 between the two side . but then that get superseded on october 7th by the horror that we saw that day committed by hamas and then by the scale and damage caused by israel ’ s bombing campaign in it counterattack . and we begin to see not only revulsion and horror at what hamas had done in early october , but also growing criticism and condemnation of what israel and it air force did in it response . you ’ ll remember that earlier this year , the international court of justice , a separate court also in the hague , began to address claim that israel wa and is committing a genocide in gaza , a claim that israel strongly denies . right . that wa the case that south africa brought . we did an episode about that . yes , exactly . so a the world ’ s attention focus on this new conflict , so doe karim khan ’ s . also today , the international criminal court ’ s chief prosecutor , karim khan , qc , ha wrapped up a visit to israel and the occupied west bank . khan ha visited the region to investigate if war crime were committed on october 7th . we start to see him arrive in israel visiting some of the site that hamas attacked last year , talking to survivor , talking to leader , reviewing security camera footage , and so on . i have just come from the border of the rafah crossing , and we could see gaza , at least we could see crane that were on the territory of gaza . and he also visited the rafah crossing between egypt and gaza , talk to palestinian . at the ministry of justice in ramallah , the chief prosecutor of the world ’ s highest court . he go to the israeli occupied west bank , to ramallah , where the palestinian authority is based , building up evidence that led to this announcement on monday . [ music playing ] today , i ’ m filing application for warrant of arrest before pre-trial chamber i of the international criminal court . and he make this very dramatic announcement in a vid

Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement the temporary pier is one of few remaining entry point for aid shipment since israel began an incursion into rafah , in southern gaza , earlier this month . bygaya gupta none of the food and supply that have entered the gaza strip through a u.s . - built temporary pier in it first five day of operation have been distributed to palestinian by aid organization , gen . patrick s . ryder , the pentagon spokesman , said at a news briefing on tuesday . general ryder said that 569 metric ton of aid had made it onto gaza ’ s shore , but that those supply had yet to be parceled out by humanitarian organization . on saturday , hungry crowdslooted several world food program truckstransporting aid that had been delivered through the pier , prompting the agency to suspend delivery of aid arriving at the pier on sunday and monday . general ryder also said that after discussion with israel and the united nation , alternative route for the safe movement of staff and cargo had been established . the aid is now being taken to warehouse for further distribution , he said . “ we do anticipate that assistance will be distributed in the coming day , of course , condition permitting , ” he said . the temporary pier is one of few remaining entry point for aid shipment after israel ’ s incursion into rafah , in southern gaza , earlier this month . israel not only seized the rafah crossing on the border with egypt but also closed the kerem shalom crossing into israel . those were the two main entry point for truck convoy carrying aid overland . though israel ha since reopened kerem shalom , only 69 truck have entered gaza through it in the past two week , according to u.n . data . that is far fewer than the number of aid truck that were entering through the two southern border crossing before israeli troop went into rafah . that number peaked at 340 truck a day . the 569 metric ton that have arrived at the pier so far are a fraction of the amount of aid that wa entering gaza through land route before israel seized the rafah crossing . the united nation estimate that truck carrying food to gaza have been loaded with roughly 15 to 30 metric ton each . the pier system , which cost an estimated $ 300 million , became operational on thursday , after it wa connected to the mediterranean shore in central gaza . on friday , the first truck of aid beganmoving ashore . so far , however , the operation ha fallen short of it goal of bringing in 90 truck a day and eventually ramping up to 150 truck . general ryder said that more aid wa on the way but that the u.s . military wa taking a “ crawl , walk , run ” approach , working out the logistical hurdle and taking into account security condition . “ so i think you ’ re going to see a we work together the amount of aid increase , and the ability to get it distributed increase , ” he said . gaya guptais a reporter covering breaking news and a member of the 2023-24times fellowship class , a program for journalist early in their careers.more about gaya gupta advertisement
title: no gaza aid delivered through u.s . - built pier ha been distributed , pentagon say

resolution this week that would demand an immediate cease-fire and a halt to israel ’ s military operation in the city of rafah . but they will have to overcome the objection of the united state , which ha veto power on the council and ha signaled it will not support the resolution in it current form . algeria , the only arab representative in the current makeup of the security council , drafted and circulated the one-page resolution , which say that “ israel , the occupying power , shall immediately halt it military offensive , and any other action in rafah . ” it call for “ an immediate cease-fire respected by all party , and also demand the immediate and unconditional release of all hostage . ” the council held back-to-back meeting on the war in gaza on tuesday and wednesday , first an emergency session behind closed door about the strike on the encampment in rafah and then a scheduled monthly open meeting on the israeli-palestinian conflict . algeria ’ s resolution wa expected to go to a vote in the coming day . “ the human cost is self-evident and appalling , ” algeria ’ s ambassador , amar bendjama , told the council on wednesday . “ these crime speak for themselves . ” one u.s . official , who spoke on condition of anonymity because he wa not authorized to speak publicly , said the united state would block the current version of the Body Text: israel-hamaswar advertisement the disclosure by the military wa likely to add pressure on prime minister benjamin netanyahu ’ s government to move forward with a cease-fire deal . byanushka patil the israeli military said on monday that four more hostage who were abducted in the hamas-led oct . 7 attack had died month ago in gaza , a disclosure that wa likely to add pressure on prime minister benjamin netanyahu ’ s government to move forward with a cease-fire deal . rear adm . daniel hagari , spokesman for the israeli military , said at a news briefing on monday that the four hostage were believed to have been killed together “ several month ago ” near khan younis , in southern gaza , while israeli force were operating in the area . the military identified the men a haim perry , yoram metzger , amiram cooper and nadav popplewell . admiral hagari said the decision to announce the hostage ’ death on monday wa based on “ additional intelligence , which had been verified recently , making it possible to determine today that the four are no longer alive , ” adding that he knew “ difficult question ” would arise about the circumstance of their death . the family of the four had been notified that their body were being held by hamas , and the circumstance of their death were “ still under examination , ” the israeli military said . the hostage family forum , a support group , released a statement demanding that the israeli government immediately negotiate a deal for the remaining hostage to be freed . it said the four who were declared dead on monday were alive when they were kidnapped from kibbutz nirim and kibbutz nir oz , and that there had been “ sign of life ” in the interim period . “ their murder in captivity is a mark of disgrace and a sad reflection on the significance of delaying previous deal , ” the group said . the pressure on mr . netanyahu to end the fighting in gaza ha grown since last week , when president biden publicly endorsed what he said wa a three-phase cease-fire proposal put forward by israel . but mr . netanyahu ’ s far-right political ally havethreatened to collapse his governmentif israel make any agreement
